questions.text: Early-onset pre-eclampsia is defined as pre-eclampsia occurring before which gestational age?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 34 weeks

Explanation:

Early-onset pre-eclampsia is defined as pre-eclampsia that occurs before 34 weeks of gestation.
 

Preeclampsia:

  • Types of Preeclampsia:
    • Early-Onset Preeclampsia:
      • Occurs at <34 weeks gestation.
      • Etiology: Defective placenta due to altered trophoblast invasion and placental ischemia.
      • Features: Placental infarcts, arterial sclerosis, and hypoperfusion.
    • Late-Onset Preeclampsia:
  • Occurs at ≥34 weeks gestation.
  • Etiology: Healthy placenta interacting with maternal factors, causing microvascular damage and endothelial dysfunction.
  • Features: Maintained placental perfusion; managed expectantly until 37 weeks if stable.
  • Clinical Presentations:
    • New-onset headache unresponsive to medication.
    • Visual disturbances.
    • Right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, often with nausea or vomiting.
    • Shortness of breath.
    • Worsened swelling beyond baseline pregnancy-related symptoms.
  • Physical Findings:
    • Elevated blood pressure:
      • SBP ≥140 mmHg or DBP ≥90 mmHg on two measurements at least 4 hours apart.
      • Severe hypertension: SBP ≥160 mmHg or DBP ≥110 mmHg.
    • Edema: Dependent (lower extremities) or independent (face, hands).
    • Lung examination for pulmonary disturbances.
    • Tenderness in the right upper quadrant or epigastric area.
  • Laboratory Tests:
  • Proteinuria: Urine dipstick ≥2+, 24-hour collection ≥300 mg, or protein/creatinine ratio ≥0.3.
  • Thrombocytopenia: Platelet count <100 K/mm³.
  • Impaired Liver Function: Liver enzymes >2 times the upper limit of normal.
  • Renal Insufficiency: Serum creatinine ≥1.1 mg/dL or double baseline levels.
  • Management:
    • Antihypertensive Therapy:
      • For severe hypertension (SBP ≥160 mmHg or DBP ≥110 mmHg):
  • IV Medications: Labetalol, hydralazine.
  • Oral Medications: Immediate-release nifedipine.
  • For maintenance:
    • PO Medications: Labetalol, extended-release nifedipine, or clonidine.
  • Seizure Prophylaxis:
    • First-Line: IV magnesium sulfate.
    • Alternatives (if contraindicated): Levetiracetam or benzodiazepines for seizure treatment.
  • Definitive Treatment: Delivery of the fetus is the only definitive cure.
  • Delivery Timing:
    • Gestational Hypertension or Preeclampsia without Severe Features: Deliver at 37 weeks.
    • Severe Features at ≥34 weeks: Delivery after maternal stabilization.
    • Severe Features <34 weeks: Expectant management with close monitoring and antenatal steroids for fetal lung maturation if stable.

questions.text: When is delayed cord clamping recommended?

choices.text: Term and preterm babies, irrespective of birth weights
Vigorous term and preterm babies requiring resuscitation
Vigorous term babies not requiring resuscitation
All term babies born at 37 weeks

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Term and preterm babies irrespective of birth weights

Explanation:

Delayed cord clamping is done in term and preterm babies, irrespective of birth weight.

Delayed Umbilical Cord Clamping:

 

Timing

Recommended delay: At least 30-60 seconds after birth for vigorous term and preterm infants (per ACOG).

Benefits for Term Infants
  • Increased Hemoglobin Levels: Higher levels at birth.
  • Improved Iron Stores: Better reserves during the first several months of life.
  • Positive Developmental Impact: Potential improvement in neurodevelopmental outcomes.

Benefits for Preterm Infants
  • Improved Circulation: Enhanced transitional circulation to support physiological adaptation.
  • Higher RBC Volume: Better blood volume establishment.
  • Reduced Complications:
    • Lower rates of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC).
    • Reduced incidence of intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH).
  • Decreased Need for Blood Transfusions: Fewer transfusions required in neonatal care.

Maternal Safety
  • No significant increase in postpartum hemorrhage or blood loss.
  • No differences in postpartum hemoglobin levels or the need for maternal transfusion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a physiological change seen in pregnancy?

choices.text: Increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure after 6 weeks
Peripheral resistance to insulin leading to hyperinsulinemia
Increased plasma volume and RBC mass

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure after 6 weeks

Explanation:

In pregnancy, an increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure after 6 weeks is not a physiological change.
 

Blood Pressure in Pregnancy:

  • Declines early in pregnancy, reaching a nadir at 24-26 weeks; diastolic pressure decreases more than systolic.
  • Positional Changes: BP is lower in lateral positions compared to sitting or supine positions.
  • Supine Hypotensive Syndrome: Uterus compresses great vessels, causing significant hypotension in some women.

 

Blood Volume in Pregnancy:

  • Hypervolemia: Blood volume increases by 40-45% above nonpregnant levels by 32-34 weeks of gestation. In some cases, blood volume nearly doubles.
  • Plasma and Erythrocyte Mass:
    • Plasma volume increases more than erythrocyte mass.
    • Erythrocyte volume increases by ~450 mL due to moderate bone marrow erythroid hyperplasia and elevated plasma erythropoietin levels. (Option D)
  • Hemoglobin and Hematocrit: Hemoglobin concentration decreases slightly, averaging 12.5 g/dL at term.

 

Metabolic Changes in Pregnancy:

  • Glucose Levels: Characterized by mild fasting hypoglycemia, postprandial hyperglycemia, and hyperinsulinemia. (Option B)
  • Insulin Sensitivity: Reduced by 30-70% in late pregnancy due to:
    • Hormones: Progesterone, cortisol, placentally derived growth hormone, and prolactin.
    • Cytokines: Tumor necrosis factor and leptin.
  • Postprandial Glucose: Elevated due to insulin resistance and augmented hepatic gluconeogenesis.
  • Fasting State: (OptionC)
    • Lower glucose and amino acids.
    • Higher free fatty acids, triglycerides, and cholesterol.
    • Ketonemia develops rapidly during prolonged fasting.

questions.text: Instrument-assisted delivery is not indicated in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cephalo pelvic disproportion

Explanation:

Cephalo pelvic disproportion is not an indication for instrument-assisted delivery.
 

Instrumental delivery

Indications

Contraindications
  • Fetal head at +2 station or below, along with
    • Maternal exhaustion (Option B)
    • Prolonged second-stage labor (Option C)
    • Nonreassuring fetal heart rates and premature placental separation. (Option A)
 
  • Maternal reasons for Operative Vaginal Delivery involve conditions that limit effective pushing or require rapid delivery, such as
    • Severe pulmonary hypertension
    • Neurological diseases
    • Serious cardiac disorders.
  • Mentoposterior position or face presentation
  • Cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Contracted pelvis
  • Preterm delivery
  • Intrauterine death
  • After coming head of Brech
  • Bony deformities of the fetus, such as osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Coagulopathy in the fetus.

questions.text: In the context of labor and delivery, what does "restitution" refer to?

choices.text: Passive movement of head due to untwisting of neck
Movement of the head by 1/8th of the circle due to torsion
Stretching of the vulval outlet by the head
External rotation after delivery of shoulder

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Passive movement of head due to untwisting of neck

Explanation:

Restitution is the passive movement of head due to untwisting of neck.
 

Restitution:

  • It is the repositioning of the fetal head attitude immediately after delivery, returning it to normal alignment with the body.
  • It involves visible external movement of the fetal head to correct the torsion of the neck sustained during internal rotation. The direction of this movement is opposite to that of internal rotation (45°).
  • This movement allows the head to align with the shoulders, with the occiput pointing towards the maternal thigh of the corresponding side where it originally lies.
  • As restitution occurs, the fetal head reaches a transverse position, and the fetal body aligns its bisacromial diameter (the distance across the shoulders) with the anteroposterior diameter of the pelvic outlet.
  • As a result, one shoulder moves anteriorly, positioning behind the symphysis, while the other shoulder moves posteriorly.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT part of AMTSL?

choices.text: Delivery of placenta by controlled cord traction
Administration of oxytocin after shoulder delivery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bimanual compression

Explanation:

Bimanual compression is not a part of AMTSL.
 

Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL):

  • AMTSL is a set of practices aimed at enhancing uterine contractions to facilitate placental delivery and prevent primary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).
  • Key Steps:
    • Administration of Uterotonic Medication: (Option D)
  • A uterotonic drug, such as oxytocin, is administered within one minute of the baby's birth or immediately after the delivery of the anterior shoulder.
  • Significance: This is the most critical step in promoting uterine contractions and reducing bleeding.
  • Delayed Cord Clamping:
    • The umbilical cord is clamped and cut 1–3 minutes after the baby is delivered.
    • Purpose: Optimizes neonatal blood volume and reduces the risk of anemia.
  • Controlled Cord Traction (CCT): (Option B)
    • The placenta is delivered using a modified technique (Brandt-Andrews method), involving gentle pulling on the cord while supporting the uterus.
    • Benefit: Helps prevent uterine inversion and ensures safe placental delivery.
  • Assessment of Uterine Tone:
    • Intermittently check the uterine fundus to confirm adequate tone and contractility.
    • Routine uterine massage (Option A) is no longer universally recommended but may be performed if needed.

questions.text: This instrument is contraindicated for?
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a forceps used for assisted vaginal delivery.

 

Forceps delivery is contraindicated in obstructed labor because the fetus cannot be safely delivered vaginally due to cephalopelvic disproportion or other causes of obstruction. Applying forceps in such cases may lead to maternal and fetal complications like uterine rupture or birth trauma.


 

Instrument

Description

Piper forceps

  • Asymmetrical blades (one solid, one fenestrated)
  • Specifically for the after-coming head in breech deliveries.
  • Allows application when access to the fetal head is limited.
  • Designed for quick delivery of head-in breech births
  • It has distinct perineal curve, allows for application to the aftercoming head in breech delivery. (Option C)

Simpson forceps
  • Long, curved blades.
  • Sliding lock mechanism.
  • Versatile - used for outlet and low-cavity applications.
  • Accommodates various fetal head sizes.
  • One of the most commonly used forceps.

Wrigley's forceps

 
  • Short, slightly curved blades.
  • Fixed English-style lock.
  • Designed for low or outlet forceps deliveries.
  • It is easier to manoeuvre when the fetal head is very low or visible.

Kielland forceps
  • Long, almost straight blades
  • Adjustable pivot.
  • Designed for rotation of the fetal head.
  • Useful for occiput transverse positions. (Option D)
  • Can accommodate asynclitism (tilted fetal head).

 

Caesarean section (Option A): Forceps can be used in cesarean deliveries to assist in delivering the fetal head, especially in cases of deep engagement or difficult extraction.

questions.text: Following image denote which side of placenta?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts fetal surface of placenta.

 

The placenta has 2 surfaces:

Maternal surface (Basal plate)
(Options B & D)

Fetal surface (Chorionic plate)
  • Adherent to the uterine wall.
  • It is rough, dull and dark red in colour
  • It is divided into cotyledons by decidual septum.
  • It helps anchor the placenta to the uterus.
  • Contains maternal blood sinus.
  • Receives blood from spiral arteries.
  • The umbilical cord is attached to the fetal surface.
  • It is smooth, shiny and bluish-purple.
  • It is covered with amnion.
  • Takes part in gaseous and nutritional exchange.
  • Highly vascular with fetal capillaries.
  • Facilitates nutritional exchange via chorionic villi.


Decidual surface (Option C) refers to the decidua basalis, the maternal tissue that interacts with the placenta. It is not an independent placental surface but contributes to the maternal side.

questions.text: Which findings are suggestive of tubal pregnancy?

choices.text: Ovarian mass with single layer of endometrium
Adnexal mass with empty uterus and fluid in pelvis

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Adnexal mass with empty uterus and fluid in pelvis

Explanation:

 

Tubal (ectopic) pregnancy occurs when a fertilized ovum implants outside the uterine cavity, most commonly in the fallopian tube. The characteristic ultrasound findings suggestive of a tubal pregnancy include:

  1. Adnexal mass – Represents the ectopic pregnancy, often seen as a tubal ring or a gestational sac outside the uterus.
  2. Empty uterus – Absence of an intrauterine gestational sac despite a positive pregnancy test.
  3. Fluid in the pelvis – Suggests hemoperitoneum due to rupture or bleeding from the ectopic site.

 

Ovarian mass with single layer of endometrium (Option A) suggests an ovarian pathology (e.g., corpus luteum cyst), not tubal pregnancy.

 

Adnexal mass with empty uterus (Option B): While this is suggestive, the presence of fluid in the pelvis increases suspicion of rupture.


Trilayer endometrium without adnexal mass (Option C): A trilaminar endometrium is seen in normal early pregnancy or luteal phase and does not indicate an ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: What stage of embryonic development is shown in the following image?
questions.solution:
The first week of embryonic development begins with fertilization and progresses through cleavage, morula, and blastocyst formation, ending with the initial stages of implantation.

The given image represents a blastocyst, characterized by:

  • A fluid-filled cavity (blastocoel).
  • An outer trophoblast layer (forms the placenta).
  • An inner cell mass (forms the embryo).

 

 

DAY

EVENT

Day 0

Fertilization: The sperm fertilizes the egg in the fallopian tube, forming a zygote (single diploid cell)

Day 1

Two cell stage

Day 2

Four cell stage

Day 3

Twelve cell stage

Day 4

Morula Formation: The zygote becomes a solid ball of 16-32 cells. (Option A)

Day 5

Blastocyst Formation: The morula continues to divide and develops a blastocoel, trophoblast, and inner cell mass

Day 6&7

Implantation begins: Blastocyst attaches to the endometrial lining of the uterus and trophoblast begins to invade the uterine wall to start implantation.

Day 14–21

Gastrulation begins: The inner cell mass differentiates into three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm), forming the gastrula. (Option D)

 


Ova (Option B): The unfertilized egg cell (ovum) before fertilization. It contains haploid genetic material and is surrounded by the zona pellucida.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 33 weeks gestation presents for a routine prenatal visit. She reports decreased fetal movements over the past two days. She has a history of gestational diabetes, and her pregnancy has been otherwise uneventful. The doctor decides to perform antepartum fetal surveillance. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial test to assess the fetal well-being in this scenario?

choices.text:
Biophysical profile

Contraction Stress test

Non Stress test

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Non Stress test

 

Explanation:

  • The NST is a non-invasive, quick, and reliable method to assess fetal heart rate response to fetal movements, which is crucial given the reported decrease in fetal movements.
  • During an NST, the mother is placed in a comfortable position, and external monitors are attached to her abdomen to record the fetal heart rate and any fetal movements for 20 minutes.
  • A reactive NST (presence of accelerations in fetal heart rate with movements) indicates good fetal health, while a non-reactive NST (lack of sufficient accelerations) may necessitate further testing or intervention.

 

Antepartum fetal surveillance:

 

Fetal movement

Maternal observation and recording of fetal movements to assess fetal well-being and activity levels.

Non-stress test (NST)

Monitors fetal heart rate acceleration in response to fetal movements to assess fetal well-being.

Biophysical profile (BPP)

(Option B ruled out)

Assesses fetal well-being based on fetal heart rate accelerations, fetal movements, muscle tone, breathing movements, and amniotic fluid volume

Doppler velocimetry

Uses ultrasound to assess blood flow in fetal vessels like umbilical artery,middle cerebral artery (MCA), and ductus venosus aiding in the evaluation of fetal well-being and placental function

Amniotic fluid index (AFI)

(Option A ruled out)

Measures the depth of amniotic fluid to assess fetal well-being and detect potential complications like oligohydramnios or polyhydramnios

Contraction stress test (CST)

(Option C ruled out)

Evaluates fetal heart rate response to uterine contractions to assess fetal well-being and uteroplacental function under controlled stress conditions.

 

BPP, CST, AFI are not the initial tests that are performed as they are either invasive (CST) or time consuming (BPP) or do not properly tell us about fetal movements (AFI).

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and a history of amenorrhea for 6 weeks. Transvaginal ultrasound does not show an intrauterine gestational sac or features suggestive of ectopic pregnancy. Her serum β-hCG is 1,200 IU/L, which is below the discriminatory zone. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct option: C) Repeat β-hCG after 48 hours

Explanation:
In a hemodynamically stable patient, when β-hCG levels are below the discriminatory zone (<1,500–2,000 IU/L) and ultrasound findings are inconclusive, the next step is to repeat β-hCG testing after 48 hours to assess the trend.

  • A doubling β-hCG level suggests a normal intrauterine pregnancy.

  • A plateauing or declining β-hCG raises suspicion of an ectopic pregnancy or early pregnancy loss.

 

Investigations for ectopic pregnancy:

  • Blood examination should be done as a routine for:
    • Haemoglobin
    • ABO and Rh grouping
    • Total white cell count and differential count
    • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
  • Estimation of β-hCG: The suspicious find­ings are:
    • Lower concentration of β-hCG compared to normal intrauterine pregnancy
    • Plasma concentration does not double in 48 hours like in normal pregnancy
  • Sonography (TVS): The diagnostic features are:
    • Absence of intrauterine pregnancy with a positive pregnancy test.
    • Fluid (echogenic) in the pouch of Douglas.
    • Adnexal mass clearly separated from the ovary (Blob sign).
    • Rarely cardiac motion may be seen in an unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy.
  • Combination of quantitative β-hCG values and sonog­raphy: TVS provides visualization of a well-formed intrauterine gestational sac as early as 4–5 weeks from the last menstrual period.
  • The lowest level of serum β-hCG at which a gestational sac is consistently visible using TVS (discriminatory zone) is ≥ 1,500 IU/L.
  • So if the beta-hCG level is ≥ 1,500 and no intrauterine pregnancy is seen, an ectopic pregnancy is highly suspected.
  • Laparoscopy offers benefits in cases of confusion with other pelvic lesions.
  • Dilatation and curettage: Identification of decidua without villi structure is suggestive.
  • Serum progesterone: A level greater than 25 ng/mL is suggestive of viable intrauterine pregnancy whereas a level less than 5 ng/mL suggests an ectopic or abnormal intrauterine pregnancy.
  • Laparotomy offers benefits when in doubt.

Laparoscopy (Option A) is reserved for cases with significant clinical suspicion of ectopic pregnancy or instability.

Methotrexate therapy (Option B) is initiated only after a confirmed diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy.

Dilatation and curettage (Option D) is used when miscarriage is suspected and histological confirmation is needed.

questions.text: A 32 y/o pregnant woman presents for her routine antenatal check-up at 28 weeks gestation. She has a history of obesity but no previous history of diabetes. Her fasting plasma glucose level is 104 mg/dL, and her 2-hour plasma glucose level after a 75g Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) is 167 mg/dL. Based on these findings, what is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Start lifestyle modifications and repeat OGTT at 32 weeks gestation.
Diagnose her with pre-existing diabetes and initiate insulin therapy.
Diagnose her with GDM and initiate dietary modifications with close monitoring of blood glucose levels.
Monitor her closely without intervention since her glucose levels are borderline.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Diagnose her with GDM and initiate dietary modifications with close monitoring of blood glucose levels.

 

Explanation:

 

Diagnosis

Gestational Diabetes

Pre-existing Diabetes

Timing

During pregnancy

Present before conception

Criteria

Fasting Plasma glucose

92 mg/dL

126 mg/dL (on two occasions)

1-hour plasma glucose

180 mg/dL

≥200 mg/dL (with hyperglycemic symptoms)

2-hour plasma glucose

153 mg/dL

≥200 mg/dL (during an OGTT in asymptomatic individuals)

HbA1c

≥5.7-6.4%

≥6.5%

Management

Resolves after delivery.

Requires intensive management before and during pregnancy.

 

  • After experiencing gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) during pregnancy, a mother may have an increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes in later life.
  • Lifestyle modifications are appropriate, but immediate diagnosis and management of GDM are necessary.
  • Monitoring without intervention is inappropriate because the patient meets the criteria for GDM diagnosis and requires management to optimize maternal and fetal outcomes.

questions.text: During the active management of the third stage of labor, which intervention is recommended to prevent postpartum hemorrhage primarily due to uterine atony?

choices.text: Immediate administration of 20 units of undiluted oxytocin intravenously
Vigorous fundal massage combined with a uterotonic agent
Controlled cord traction with immediate removal of the placenta

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vigorous fundal massage combined with a uterotonic agent

 

Explanation:

  • Vigorous fundal massage helps to maintain uterine tone and prevent uterine atony, a common cause of postpartum hemorrhage.
  • Combining it with a uterotonic agent like oxytocin further enhances uterine contraction, reducing the risk of excessive bleeding.

 

Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) for PPH

 

Uterine Massage
  • Always palpate the uterine fundus after placental delivery.
  • Vigorous fundal massage, combined with a uterotonic agent, is recommended to prevent PPH due to uterine atony.
  • During immediate PPH, perform uterine massage while evaluating for other bleeding sources and administering uterotonic agents.

Oxytocin
  • Recommended by WHO as a first-line prophylactic treatment for postpartum hemorrhage.
  • Administer 20 units of oxytocin in 1,000 mL of crystalloid solution intravenously at 10 mL/min for a dose of 200 mU/min.
  • Never administer oxytocin as an undiluted bolus due to risks of severe hypotension or cardiac arrhythmias.(Option A)
  • Intravenous oxytocin is also a first-line treatment for uterine atony.
  • Oxytocin 10 units can be given IM with the delivery of the anterior shoulder (Option B)

Delayed Cord Clamping/Controlled Cord Traction (CCT)
  • If placental separation is evident, perform expression via fundal pressure or controlled cord traction.
  • If the placenta is not separated, perform manual removal under general anaesthesia.
  • Delivery of the placenta by cord traction before placental separation especially in an atonic uterus may cause uterine inversion. (Option D)

questions.text: A woman diagnosed with impending eclampsia is started on the Pritchard regimen for magnesium sulfate administration. Under which of the following conditions should the treatment be stopped?

choices.text: Urine output less than 60 ml in 4 hours

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Urine output less than 60 ml in 4 hours:

  • Low urine output less than 100 ml in 4 hours: Indicates potential renal impairment, which can lead to the accumulation of magnesium and increase the risk of toxicity.
  • While this is a concerning sign, depending on the overall clinical assessment, treatment should be carefully monitored rather than immediately stopped.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Respiratory rate (RR) < 18 breaths per minute:

  • Magnesium sulfate toxicity can cause respiratory depression.
  • A respiratory rate below 14 breaths per minute is a critical sign that the magnesium levels may be too high, warranting the cessation of the treatment and administration of calcium gluconate as an antidote.

 

Option B - Visual disturbances start:

  • Visual disturbances are a symptom of worsening preeclampsia or impending eclampsia rather than a sign of magnesium toxicity. Therefore, it would not indicate stopping the Pritchard regimen but might require further management of preeclampsia.

 

Option C - Knee jerk reflex is present:

  • The presence of the knee jerk (patellar) reflex indicates that magnesium levels are within a safe range.
  • The absence of this reflex (areflexia) would indicate potential toxicity.
  • Thus, a present knee-jerk reflex does not necessitate stopping the treatment.

questions.text: What is the preferred method of delivery in A cephalic lie and B cephalic lie?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Normal delivery in both:

  • A cephalic lie (where the head is down) and B cephalic lie (another variation of head-down position) are typically both suitable for vaginal delivery unless there are specific indications for a cesarean section.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - LSCS, vaginal:

  • Cesarean sections are required for breech presentations, not in a cephalic lie

Option B - Vaginal, LSCS:

  • This option implies a vaginal delivery for A cephalic lie and a cesarean section (LSCS) for B cephalic lie. Cesarean sections are required for breech presentations, not in a cephalic lie

Option D - LSCS in both:

  • This option suggests a cesarean section for both A and B cephalic lies, which is incorrect. Cesarean sections are required for breech presentations.

questions.text: The flexion point in a ventouse delivery is located at which of the following positions on the fetal head?

choices.text: 3 cm posterior to the anterior fontanelle
3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
6 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
Midway between the anterior and posterior fontanelle

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle:

  • The flexion point, crucial for ventouse delivery, is located 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle. Placing the ventouse cup here helps achieve proper flexion of the fetal head, leading to the smallest diameter (suboccipitobregmatic) of the head passing through the birth canal.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - 3 cm posterior to the anterior fontanelle:

  • This option refers to a point on the fetal head closer to the posterior fontanelle but is not accurate for the flexion point used in ventouse delivery.

Option C - 6 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle:

  • This would place the point closer to the anterior fontanelle, which is not the correct position for the flexion point in ventouse delivery.

Option D - Midway between the anterior and posterior fontanelle:

This is a central point on the fetal head, but it is not the specific flexion point used for ventouse delivery, which is 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle.

questions.text: Which of the following is the anticoagulation of choice for a pregnant female at 36 weeks of gestation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Heparin:

  • Heparin, specifically unfractionated heparin (UFH), is the anticoagulant of choice in late pregnancy ( At/more than 36 weeks). Heparin does not cross the placenta, making it safe for the fetus.
  • In the final weeks of pregnancy, UFH is preferred over low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) like enoxaparin because it has a shorter half-life and can be quickly reversed if needed during labor or in case of delivery.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Warfarin:

  • Warfarin is a vitamin K antagonist and is contraindicated during pregnancy, especially in the third trimester, due to its teratogenic effects and risk of fetal bleeding. Warfarin can cross the placenta and may cause fetal complications such as fetal warfarin syndrome and intracranial hemorrhage.

Option C - Apixaban:

  • Apixaban is a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) that is not recommended during pregnancy due to limited data on its safety and the risk of placental transfer. It is not typically used in pregnant women.

Option D - Enoxaparin:

Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and is safe during most of the pregnancy. However, as the patient approaches delivery (around 36 weeks), treatment is often switched to unfractionated heparin due to the need for rapid reversal at the time of labor or delivery.

questions.text: A pregnant female at 37 weeks of gestation presents for a routine antenatal checkup. She is currently on warfarin. What would be the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Switch to LMWH:

  • Warfarin is contraindicated in the later stages of pregnancy due to the risk of fetal complications and bleeding during delivery.
  • Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) is safer for use in pregnancy as it does not cross the placenta and reduces the risk of bleeding.
  • At 37 weeks, switching from warfarin to LMWH is the recommended step to ensure safety during the upcoming delivery.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Immediate induction:

  • Induction at 37 weeks without managing the anticoagulation could pose significant risks due to potential bleeding complications.
  • Anticoagulation should be carefully managed before considering induction, making this option inappropriate as the first step.

Option C - LSCS (Lower Segment Caesarean Section):

  • An elective caesarean section would require careful planning, including discontinuing warfarin and possibly switching to LMWH beforehand to manage bleeding risks.
  • However, LSCS is not the immediate next step without addressing anticoagulation.

Option D - Continue the same:

  • Continuing warfarin is not recommended at this stage of pregnancy due to the increased risk of fetal bleeding and complications during delivery.
  • Thus, this is not the correct approach.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with a history suggestive of hyperthyroidism at 8 weeks of gestation (POG). What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Propylthiouracil (PTU):

  • Correct Answer: PTU is the drug of choice for treating hyperthyroidism during the first trimester of pregnancy. This is because it has a lower risk of causing congenital abnormalities compared to Methimazole. After the first trimester, treatment may be switched to Methimazole due to PTU's risk of hepatotoxicity.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Methimazole:

  • Methimazole is generally avoided during the first trimester of pregnancy due to its association with congenital anomalies, such as aplasia cutis (a congenital absence of skin) and other birth defects. It can be used in the second and third trimesters when the risk of these anomalies decreases.

Option C - Carbimazole:

  • Carbimazole is a prodrug of Methimazole and carries similar risks. It is also associated with congenital abnormalities when used in the first trimester and is therefore not recommended during early pregnancy.

Option D - Propranolol:

  • Propranolol is a beta-blocker used to manage symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as tachycardia, tremors, and anxiety. However, it is not a definitive treatment for hyperthyroidism and is not the drug of choice for managing the condition itself, particularly in pregnancy.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a G2P1L1 woman with a history of hysterectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Placenta accreta

Explanation:

  • Placenta accreta is a condition where the placenta attaches too deeply to the uterine wall and does not separate easily after delivery.
  • In women who have undergone a hysterectomy, the abnormal attachment of the placenta(In the image) may occur if there is retained uterine tissue or during a planned cesarean section where a partial uterus remains. This makes placenta accreta the most likely diagnosis in this scenario.

 

Incorrect Options:

(Option B) Placenta inversion:

  • Placenta inversion occurs when the placenta detaches and pulls the uterus inside-out during delivery. This is a rare but serious complication often associated with excessive traction on the umbilical cord. It is not typically related to a history of hysterectomy and is therefore less likely in this case.

(Option C) Placenta abruption:

  • Placenta abruption involves the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus, leading to bleeding and potential complications for both mother and fetus. While placenta abruption is an obstetric emergency, it is not directly linked to a history of hysterectomy and does not fit the clinical context provided.

(Option D) Placenta previa:

Placenta previa occurs when the placenta covers the cervix, causing bleeding in the latter part of pregnancy. It is more common in women with a history of cesarean sections but is not typically associated with a hysterectomy. Additionally, placenta previa is usually diagnosed via ultrasound before delivery and does not directly explain the clinical scenario of a woman with a hysterectomy.

questions.text: A pregnant woman has just delivered a healthy baby via normal delivery. What is the earliest time at which an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) can be inserted?
questions.solution:
Correct Options A - Within 48 hours:

  • An IUCD can be safely inserted within 48 hours postpartum. The IUCD is often inserted after the placenta is delivered.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - After 6 weeks:

  • This is a common time for IUCD insertion if it wasn't done immediately postpartum. After 6 weeks, the uterus has typically returned to its normal size, and the risk of expulsion is lower compared to immediate insertion. However, this is not the earliest time.

Option C - After 3 months:

  • While an IUCD can be inserted at this time, it is not necessary to wait this long. Waiting until 3 months postpartum is usually done only if there are specific concerns, but it is not the earliest time for insertion.

Option D - After 6 months:

  • Like the 3-month option, insertion at 6 months is possible but unnecessarily delayed. At 6 months, many women may be using other contraceptive methods, and the window for the earliest safe insertion has long passed.

questions.text: Identify the degree of tear shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 3rd Degree:

  • Involves the vaginal mucosa, perineal skin, perineal muscles, and extends to the anal sphincter. There are further sub-classifications:
    • 3a: Less than 50% of the external anal sphincter (EAS) thickness is torn.
    • 3b: More than 50% of the EAS thickness is torn.
    • 3c: Both the EAS and internal anal sphincter (IAS) are torn.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1st Degree:

  • Involves only the vaginal mucosa and perineal skin. The underlying muscle tissue remains intact. This is the least severe form of tear.

Option B - 2nd Degree:

  • Extends through the vaginal mucosa, perineal skin, and perineal muscles, but does not involve the anal sphincter. This is more severe than a 1st-degree tear but still does not affect the anal sphincter.

Option D - 4th Degree:

  • The tear extends through the vaginal mucosa, perineal skin, perineal muscles, the anal sphincter, and into the rectal mucosa, causing the most severe injury.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Pipers:

  • Pipers forceps are specifically designed for the delivery of the after-coming head in breech presentations. They are characterized by a reverse pelvic curve, allowing safe application to the head during breech delivery, which is crucial for avoiding injury to the baby’s head and neck.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Kielland:

  • Kielland forceps are designed with a sliding lock and minimal pelvic curve, often used for rotational deliveries in cases of fetal malposition. They are known for their distinct ability to rotate the fetal head.

Option B - Wrigley:

  • Wrigley forceps are smaller, lighter forceps primarily used for low-forceps deliveries or during cesarean sections to assist in delivering the baby’s head. They have a short length, making them ideal for low pelvic use.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for External Cephalic Version (ECV)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Primigravida:

  • Primigravida is not a contraindication for External Cephalic Version. The procedure can be performed on first-time mothers as long as there are no other complicating factors.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Placenta previa:

  • Placenta previa is a contraindication for ECV because the placenta covers the cervical os, increasing the risk of severe bleeding if ECV is attempted.

Option B - Twin pregnancy:

  • Twin pregnancy is also a contraindication for ECV due to the increased risk of complications and the difficulty of safely repositioning multiple fetuses.

Option D - PROM (Premature Rupture of Membranes):

  • PROM is a contraindication for ECV because the rupture of membranes increases the risk of cord prolapse, infection, and other complications during the procedure.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Burn-Marshall Maneuver:

  • The Burn-Marshall Maneuver (often referred to as the "Burns" maneuver) is used to deliver the aftercoming head in a breech delivery. The baby is allowed to hang until the nape of the neck is visible. Gentle upward traction is applied to the fetal body to deliver the head. However, in the context of delivering the shoulders, the term may be incorrectly used; the correct term would generally be "Lovset Maneuver."

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lovset Maneuver:

  • This maneuver is used to deliver the shoulders during a breech birth. The fetal body is rotated to facilitate the delivery of the anterior shoulder, followed by the posterior shoulder.

Option C - Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit Maneuver:

  • This maneuver is used to assist the delivery of the head in a breech presentation. The fetal body is supported on the physician’s arm, and fingers are placed in the fetal mouth to provide flexion of the head while applying gentle pressure on the occiput.

questions.text: A woman presents with a twin pregnancy. On ultrasound, the estimated age of one fetus is 1 month more than the other fetus. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Superfetation:

  • In the case of superfetation, it is possible to have fetuses at different developmental stages within the same pregnancy, resulting in an age discrepancy such as one fetus being one month older than the other. This is a rare and unusual occurrence and is the most fitting diagnosis for the described scenario.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Superfecundation:

  • This refers to the fertilization of two or more eggs during the same menstrual cycle by sperm from different acts of intercourse. It results in twins or multiple births with different paternity. This does not explain fetuses of different ages in the same pregnancy.

Option C - Suppositious Child:

  • This term is used to describe a child that is believed to be a result of surrogacy or another form of childbearing that may not be biologically related to the purported parents. It does not apply to the situation of differing fetal ages.

Option D - Posthumous Child:

This refers to a child born after the death of one or both parents. This term does not relate to the condition where fetuses of different ages are present in a single pregnancy.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with an intrauterine device (IUD) in place, and the thread is clearly visible. The woman wants to keep the pregnancy. What should be done next?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Remove gently:

  • If the IUD thread is visible, the safest approach is to gently remove the IUD during the first trimester. Removal decreases the risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes, and the majority of pregnancies can proceed without complications after the IUD is removed.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Leave IUD inside:

  • Leaving the IUD in place is generally not recommended if the thread is visible because the presence of an IUD increases the risk of complications such as miscarriage, infection, and preterm birth. The preferred approach is to remove the IUD to reduce these risks.

Option C - MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy):

  • This option might be considered if the woman does not want to continue the pregnancy or if there are significant risks associated with the pregnancy. However, since the woman wants to keep the pregnancy, this option is not appropriate.

Option D - Cesarean section:

Cesarean section is not relevant at this stage, as it pertains to delivery rather than managing an early pregnancy with an IUD in place.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a known case of asthma presents with postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). Which drug is contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Carboprost:

  • Carboprost is contraindicated in patients with asthma due to its potential to cause bronchoconstriction, which can exacerbate asthma symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Methyl ergometrine:

  • This drug is used to control PPH by stimulating uterine contractions. It is not contraindicated in asthma but should be used cautiously due to its potential to increase blood pressure.

Option C - Misoprostol:

  • A prostaglandin E1 analogue commonly used to treat PPH. It has a relatively safe profile in asthmatic patients and does not cause bronchoconstriction.

Option D - Oxytocin:

  • A first-line agent for treating PPH. It stimulates uterine contractions and is safe for use in asthmatic patients, with no risk of bronchoconstriction.

questions.text: Persistent occipito-posterior (OP) face-to-pubes delivery is seen in which type of pelvis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Anthropoid:

  • The anthropoid pelvis has an oval-shaped inlet that is more elongated in the anteroposterior dimension. It is often associated with persistent occipito-posterior (OP) fetal positions and face-to-face presentations during delivery. This type of pelvis can make it more challenging for the fetus to rotate to the occipito-anterior position, leading to the persistence of the OP position.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Android:

  • The android pelvis is characterized by a heart-shaped inlet and a narrow pelvic cavity. This type of pelvis can make labor more difficult and is associated with a higher incidence of abnormal fetal positions, including the occipito-posterior position. However, it is not the most typical pelvis associated with persistent OP face to pubes delivery.

Option B - Gynecoid:

  • The gynecoid pelvis is considered the "normal" or "ideal" pelvic shape for childbirth, with a round pelvic inlet and a spacious pelvic cavity. It generally facilitates easier delivery and is less likely to cause persistent OP face-to-pubes deliveries compared to other pelvic types.

Option D - Platypelloid:

  • The platypelloid pelvis is characterized by a wide transverse diameter and a shortened anteroposterior diameter. This type of pelvis can cause difficulties in labor, but it is less commonly associated with persistent OP face-to-pubes presentations compared to the anthropoid pelvis.

questions.text: Whose opinion is not needed for Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) after 24 weeks due to fetal anomalies?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Lawyer

Explanation:

  • While legal advice may be necessary to navigate the legal aspects of MTP, their opinion is not required for the medical decision-making process regarding the termination of pregnancy due to fetal anomalies.

(Option A) Gynaecologist:

  • The opinion of a gynaecologist is essential for MTP, especially after 24 weeks, as they are responsible for assessing the health of the pregnant woman and the implications of continuing or terminating the pregnancy.

(Option B) Radiologist:

  • A radiologist’s input is crucial in cases of MTP after 24 weeks due to fetal anomalies. They provide diagnostic imaging, such as ultrasounds, to identify and confirm the presence of anomalies in the fetus.

(Option C) Lawyer:

  • A pediatrician's opinion is important in the context of MTP for severe anomalies, as they can provide insight into the potential outcomes and quality of life for the newborn if the pregnancy continues.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anencephaly:

  • This condition is characterized by the absence of a major portion of the brain and skull. On ultrasound, it presents as the absence of a normal brain structure, but it does not typically display the "Frog Eye Sign."

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hydranencephaly:

  • This condition involves the replacement of brain tissue with cerebrospinal fluid, leading to a near-complete absence of cerebral hemispheres. The ultrasound appearance is more consistent with the absence of cerebral hemispheres and a large fluid-filled cavity rather than the "Frog Eye Sign."

Option C - Spina Bifida:

Markers for Spina Bifida

  • Scalloping of frontal bones: Lemon Sign
  • Forward curvature of Cerebellum: Banana Sign

Option D - Lissencephaly:

  • This is a condition characterized by a smooth brain surface due to a lack of normal gyri and sulci. On ultrasound, it shows a smooth cerebral cortex without the typical folding patterns, but it does not typically present with the "Frog Eye Sign."

questions.text: In a pregnant woman with active genital ulcers, what is the recommended mode of delivery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - LSCS (Lower Segment Caesarean Section):

  • LSCS is the preferred method for delivery in cases where there is a risk of transmission of infections or complications during vaginal delivery. For a pregnant woman with active genital ulcers, LSCS is recommended to avoid the risk of transmission of the infection to the newborn during passage through the birth canal, which could potentially cause neonatal infection or other complications.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Classic Caesarean Section:

  • A Classic Caesarean Section involves making an incision in the upper part of the uterus. This method is less commonly used today due to increased risk of complications and longer recovery time compared to LSCS. It is typically reserved for specific obstetric indications where LSCS is not feasible.

Option C - Vaginal Delivery:

  • Vaginal delivery is generally avoided in the presence of active genital ulcers because the risk of transmitting the infection to the baby during delivery is high. Genital ulcers can be associated with infections like herpes simplex virus (HSV), which can lead to severe neonatal complications if transmitted during vaginal delivery.

Option D - Induction of Labour:

  • Induction of labor is a procedure used to start labor artificially. In the presence of active genital ulcers, inducing labor is not recommended due to the increased risk of complications and the potential for infection transmission to the newborn.

questions.text: For a woman with a 10-week period of gestation (POG) who seeks medical termination of pregnancy, the appropriate choice would be?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mifepristone and Misoprostol:

  • Mifepristone: This is a progesterone antagonist that blocks the effects of progesterone, which is necessary to maintain pregnancy. It prepares the uterus for the subsequent action of misoprostol.
  • Misoprostol: This is a prostaglandin analog that induces uterine contractions and helps expel the contents of the uterus. It is used after mifepristone to complete the abortion process.
  • Usage: This combination is widely used for medical abortion up to 10 weeks gestation and is considered safe and effective.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Dinoprost:

Dinoprost: This is a prostaglandin used to induce labor and terminate pregnancies. However, it is typically used in the second trimester rather than at 10 weeks POG. It is less commonly used compared to misoprostol for early medical abortion.

Option C - Oxytocin:

Oxytocin: This is a hormone used to induce labor by stimulating uterine contractions. It is not used for early medical abortion and is generally reserved for labor induction or management of postpartum hemorrhage.

Option D - Intrauterine Hyperosmolar Saline:

Intrauterine Hyperosmolar Saline: This is an older method of abortion used in the second trimester and involves injecting a hyperosmolar saline solution into the amniotic sac. It is not used for early-term abortions and is less common in modern practice.

questions.text: Identify the option with the least risk of TOLAC (trial of labor after cesarean)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Low-segment transverse incision

Explanation:

Low-segment transverse incision has the lowest risk for uterine rupture during trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC).

  • Incision location: Lower uterine segment
  • Direction: Horizontal (transverse)
  • Healing characteristics: Better wound healing
  • Scar strength: Superior to classical incision

Clinical Significance:

  • Lower rupture risk during subsequent pregnancies
  • Better healing due to less contractile portion of uterus
  • Preferred technique for primary cesarean sections
  • Favorable for future TOLAC

 

Classical C section (Option A): This vertical incision through the contractile portion of the uterus carries a significantly higher risk of uterine rupture (4-9%) during TOLAC. The location and direction of this incision make it a contraindication for future vaginal delivery attempts.

Pre-eclampsia (Option B): This is a medical condition that affects pregnancy but has no direct relationship to the type of uterine incision or TOLAC risk. Pre-eclampsia is a separate consideration in pregnancy management and doesn't inherently affect TOLAC decision-making.

Breech presentation (Option D): This refers to fetal positioning and is not related to the type of uterine incision or its associated risks in TOLAC. While breech presentation may influence delivery decisions, it doesn't directly impact the risk of uterine rupture during TOLAC.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 22 weeks of gestation presents with a marginal placenta on ultrasound. When is the next ultrasound recommended for reassessment
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 28 weeks

Explanation:

  • Marginal placenta is a Type 2 placenta previa where the placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Most cases resolve by 28-29 weeks of gestation
  • Resolution occurs due to placental migration through two mechanisms:
    1. Progressive increase in the length of the lower uterine segment causes the lower placental edge to relocate away from the cervical os
    2. Trophotropism (growth of trophoblastic tissue towards the fundus) leads to resolution of placenta previa.

Management Protocol:

If a marginal placenta is detected at 22 weeks:

  • First follow-up USG should be done at 28 weeks
  • If persistence is noted, another assessment is done at 38 weeks

questions.text: A married woman with a failed contraception method presents at 26 weeks of gestation. What is the appropriate course of action based on the MTP Act?

choices.text: If no fetal anomaly, continue the pregnancy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) If no fetal anomaly, continue the pregnancy

Explanation:

  • According to the latest amended MTP Act of 2023, willful termination of pregnancy is allowed up to 24 weeks of gestation
  • In this case, although contraceptive failure is an indication for medical termination, the gestational age (26 weeks) is beyond the legal limit of 24 weeks
  • Therefore, the pregnancy should be continued if there are no fetal anomalies

Other Indications for MTP:

  • Eugenic: Child is malformed
  • Teratogenic malformation
  • TORCH infections
  • Physical malformation
  • Therapeutic: Risk of life of the mother, physical or mental anomaly
  • Humanitarian: Rape

 

Husband consent (Option A):

  • The husband's consent is not required for MTP

2 doctors opinion (Option B):

  • Up to 20 weeks, a single doctor’s opinion is required. A minimum of 2 doctor’s opinions is required for 20-24 weeks.
  • Not applicable in this case as gestation is beyond 24 weeks

Medical board permission for termination (Option D):

  • Medical board permission for termination is required for special situations beyond 24 weeks of gestation
  • Not applicable here as there are no reported fetal anomalies

questions.text: Which type is not seen in twin pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Dichorionic monoamniotic:

  • Twin pregnancies can be monochorionic monoamniotic (split takes place at 9 to 12 days), monochorionic diamniotic (split at 4 to 8 days), or dichorionic diamniotic (split occurs before 3 days).
  • If the split takes place after 12 days, it results in conjoined twins.
  • Dichorionic monoamniotic twins do not occur because dichorionic twins always have separate amniotic sacs

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, C and D: Refer explanation given above

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presented with primary amenorrhea and normal sexual characteristics. Lab tests came out as: FSH-3, LH-14, with XX karyotyping. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mullerian agenesis:

  • Mullerian agenesis is a congenital disorder where the Müllerian ducts fail to develop, leading to the absence of the uterus and upper part of the vagina.
  • Patients present with primary amenorrhea but have normal secondary sexual characteristics because their ovaries and external genitalia are normal.
  • Lab tests typically show normal FSH and LH levels, and the karyotype is 46XX, which matches the given case

Incorrect Options:

Option B - AIS:

  • AIS is a condition where individuals with a 46XY karyotype are resistant to male hormones (androgens).
  • Patients have female external genitalia and secondary sexual characteristics, but no uterus, leading to primary amenorrhea.
  • However, the karyotype is 46XY, not 46XX, and the hormone levels do not match the given case

Option C - Gonadal dysgenesis:

  • Gonadal dysgenesis, such as Turner syndrome (45X) or Swyer syndrome (46XY), typically presents with elevated FSH and LH levels due to non-functioning gonads.
  • Patients often have primary amenorrhea and may have streak gonads.
  • The given lab results (FSH-3, LH-14) do not align with gonadal dysgenesis, where FSH and LH would be significantly higher

Option D - Kallman syndrome:

  • Kallman syndrome is characterized by hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and anosmia (loss of sense of smell).
  • Patients have low FSH and LH levels, delayed or absent puberty, and primary amenorrhea.
  • The given lab results (FSH-3, LH-14) do not fit Kallman syndrome, as LH is elevated in this case.

questions.text: A female in her reproductive age complains of abdominal pain associated vaginal bleeding, hypotension, and altered sensorium after 6 weeks of amenorrhea. USG shows free fluid in the peritoneum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ruptured ectopic pregnancy:

  • A ruptured ectopic pregnancy typically presents with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and free fluid in the peritoneum due to internal bleeding. This is a medical emergency and requires immediate attention.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pelvic inflammatory disease:

  • It usually presents with lower abdominal pain, fever, and vaginal discharge, but not typically associated with free fluid in the peritoneum.

Option C - Ovarian torsion:

  • Presents with sudden severe unilateral pelvic pain and sometimes nausea, but not typically with vaginal bleeding and free fluid.

Option D - Hemorrhagic corpus luteum:

  • Can cause abdominal pain and internal bleeding, but the presentation is less severe compared to a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with chronic hypertension complains of headaches and visual disturbances. What is the management in this case?

choices.text: I.V Labetalol and deliver at 37 weeks

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - IV Labetalol + MgSO4 and deliver:

  • The combination of IV Labetalol (to control blood pressure) and MgSO4 (to prevent seizures) is used to manage severe preeclampsia.
  • Immediate delivery is indicated to prevent further maternal and fetal complications.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - I.V Labetalol and deliver at 37 weeks:

  • Delayed delivery is not appropriate, given the severity of the symptoms.

Option B - Give one dose of steroid:

  • Steroids are used to mature the fetal lungs before 34 weeks.

Option C - IV Labetalol and deliver immediately:

  • MgSO4 is also needed to prevent seizures.

questions.text: An 18-year-old female at 18 weeks of gestation with a quadruple screening shows a high risk of NTD and a low risk of trisomy. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anomaly scan:

  • The next step for a high risk of neural tube defects (NTD) and low risk of trisomy indicated by a quadruple screening test is to perform an anomaly scan.
  • The anomaly scan is a non-invasive procedure and provides crucial information about the presence of structural anomalies, making it a safe first step after a screening test indicates a high risk of NTD.
  • This detailed ultrasound examination, typically performed around 18-22 weeks of gestation, helps visualize structural anomalies, including neural tube defects, and provides crucial information for further management.

Incorrect Options

Option B - Fetal free DNA testing:

  • This test is mainly used for detecting chromosomal abnormalities such as trisomies (e.g., Down syndrome) and is not effective for diagnosing structural anomalies like neural tube defects.

Option C - Amniocentesis:

  • Amniocentesis can detect certain genetic conditions and neural tube defects through the analysis of amniotic fluid
  • It is an invasive procedure with a small risk of complications, such as miscarriage.
  • It is not the immediate next step after a screening test indicating a high NTD risk. Instead, it may be considered if the anomaly scan raises further concerns.

Option D - Chorionic villi sampling (CVS):

  • CVS is used for early detection of chromosomal abnormalities and some genetic conditions but is not suitable for detecting neural tube defects.
  • It is typically performed in the first trimester and is not the next step for high NTD risk identified later in pregnancy.

questions.text: Which among the following drugs is avoid in a hypertensive female with PPH?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Methergine (Methylergonovine):

  • Methergine is contraindicated in patients with hypertension due to its potent vasoconstrictive properties
  • Methergine is an ergot alkaloid that can cause vasoconstriction, which may significantly increase blood pressure. This is particularly dangerous in hypertensive patients, as it can lead to severe hypertension and potential cerebrovascular accidents.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Carboprost:

  • Carboprost tromethamine is a prostaglandin analog used for the treatment of postpartum hemorrhage.
  • It is effective in promoting uterine contractions and is generally considered safe in hypertensive patients.

Option B - Oxytocin:

  • Oxytocin is commonly used for inducing labor and controlling postpartum hemorrhage by promoting uterine contractions.
  • It is considered safe for use in hypertensive patients and does not significantly raise blood pressure.

Option D - Prostaglandins:

  • Prostaglandins (such as Misoprostol) are used to manage postpartum hemorrhage by enhancing uterine contractions.
  • Prostaglandins are not contraindicated in hypertension.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a criterion for diagnosing IUGR?

choices.text: Umbilical artery with absent end diastolic volume

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Uterine artery PI uterus < 95:

  • Uterine artery pulsatility index (PI) is used to assess placental perfusion, but a PI < 95 is not a standard criterion for diagnosing IUGR. Instead, abnormal Doppler findings in the umbilical artery are more relevant for IUGR assessment

Incorrect Options:

Option A - AC less than 3 SD:

  • Abdominal circumference (AC) less than 3 standard deviations (SD) is a recognized criterion for diagnosing intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).

Option B - Fetal weight less than 3 SD:

  • Fetal weight less than 3 standard deviations is also a recognized criterion for IUGR diagnosis as it indicates significant growth restriction.

Option D - Umbilical artery with absent end diastolic volume:

  • Absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery Doppler is a critical finding associated with severe IUGR and poor perinatal outcomes, making it a relevant diagnostic criterion for IUGR.

questions.text: A primigravida woman with O negative blood type, whose husband has A positive blood type, received an anti-D injection at 28 weeks of pregnancy. Under which condition should she receive another anti-D injection after delivery?

choices.text: If the baby is O is positive and DCT -
If the baby is O negative and DCT +

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - If the baby is O is positive and DCT -:

  • Anti-D immunoglobulin is administered to prevent Rh immunization.
  • Postpartum anti-D is given only if the baby is Rh-positive (in this case, O positive) and the direct Coombs test (DCT) is negative, indicating no maternal antibodies have already sensitized the baby’s red blood cells.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - All cases:

  • Anti-D is not required if the baby is Rh-negative; thus, not given in all cases.

Option B - If baby negative:

  • Anti-D is unnecessary if the baby is Rh-negative as there is no risk of Rh incompatibility.

Option D - If baby O negative, DCT +:

  • If the baby is Rh-negative, anti-D is not needed regardless of the Coombs test result.

questions.text: What is the correct dose of antenatal steroids for fetal lung maturity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 h 4 dose:

  • This regimen involves administering dexamethasone 6 mg intramuscularly every 12 hours for a total of 4 doses.
  • This dosing schedule is recommended for promoting fetal lung maturity in preterm pregnancies, helping to reduce the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Betamethasone 6 mg 12 h 2 dose:

  • While betamethasone is effective, the standard dosing regimen for optimal lung maturity is 12 mg.

Option C - Dexamethasone 12 mg 24 h 2 dose:

  • This regimen involves administering dexamethasone 12 mg every 24 hours for 2 doses, which is not the typical regimen for fetal lung maturity.

Option D - Betamethasone 12 mg 12 h 4 dose:

  • This involves administering a higher number of doses than necessary. The standard protocol for betamethasone is usually 12 mg for 2 doses.

questions.text: Which hormone is not responsible for the intrauterine growth of the fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Growth hormone:

  • Growth hormone (GH) is not significantly involved in fetal growth. Its role is more prominent postnatally, where it contributes to overall growth and development after birth. Fetal growth is largely independent of GH.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Insulin:

  • Insulin is crucial for fetal growth. It promotes the uptake and utilization of glucose and amino acids, which are essential for the development of fetal tissues.

Option B - Thyroxine

  • Thyroxine (T4) is important for normal fetal growth and development, particularly for brain development and the maturation of various organs.

Option C - Insulin-like Growth Factor (IGF)

  • Insulin-like Growth Factor (IGF) plays a significant role in fetal growth. IGF-1 and IGF-2 are key regulators of cell growth and differentiation during intrauterine development.

questions.text: Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) due to contraceptive failure can be done up to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 20 weeks

Explanation: For cases of contraceptive failure, MTP can be performed for up to 20 weeks with approval from a single doctor.

  • MTP up to 20 weeks requires the opinion of one RMP.
  • MTP between 20-24 weeks requires two RMPs' opinions.
  • MTP up to 24 weeks is allowed only for rape survivors. (Option B)
  • Contraceptive failure allows MTP only up to 20 weeks.
  • After 24 weeks, MTP is permitted only for substantial fetal abnormalities, with medical board approval.
  • MTP can be performed at any time if it is immediately necessary to save the life of the pregnant woman

32 weeks (Option C): This is well beyond the legal limit for routine MTPs. Only cases with significant fetal anomalies can be considered beyond 24 weeks.

12 weeks (Option D): This is too restrictive and does not align with current guidelines for MTP in cases of contraceptive failure.

questions.text: Induction of labour is not done in which of the following ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Central placenta previa:

  • In central placenta previa, the placenta covers the cervix completely. Induction of labor is generally contraindicated in cases of central placenta previa due to the risk of significant bleeding when the cervix starts to dilate. Inducing contractions in such cases can lead to the separation of the placenta from the uterine wall, causing potentially life-threatening hemorrhage.

Incorrect Option

Option B - Gestational Hypertension (HTN): Induction of labor can be considered in cases of gestational hypertension if there is concern about maternal or fetal well-being. However, the decision depends on the severity of hypertension and other clinical factors. Induction might be recommended to avoid complications associated with prolonged hypertension, but it can be managed on a case-by-case basis.

Option C - PROM (Premature Rupture of Membranes): PROM refers to the rupture of the amniotic sac before the onset of labor. Induction of labor is often considered when PROM occurs to reduce the risk of infection to the mother and fetus due to the prolonged rupture of membranes. The timing of induction in such cases depends on various factors, including gestational age, maternal and fetal health, and the presence of infection.

Option D - Abruptio Placenta: Abruptio placenta is a condition where the placenta prematurely separates from the uterine wall before delivery. Depending on the severity of the detachment and the stability of both the mother and the fetus, induction might be considered as part of the management plan. However, cases of significant abruptio placenta might necessitate emergency delivery via cesarean section rather than induction.

questions.text: Which of the following is required for MTP at 21 weeks for a fetus diagnosed with meningomyelocele?

choices.text: Consent of husband with opinion of one doctor
Her consent with opinion of 2 doctors

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Her consent with opinion of 2 doctors:

  • In the case of medical interventions for a fetus diagnosed with meningomyelocele, the mother's consent is essential as it is her body and pregnancy. Additionally, the involvement of two doctors' opinions is a standard practice to ensure a thorough assessment of the medical situation and the proposed intervention.

Incorrect Option

Option A - Consent of husband with opinion of one doctor: This option is not applicable as the decision and consent primarily involve the pregnant woman (mother) rather than the husband. The medical decisions related to fetal conditions are typically made based on the mother's consent and medical opinions.

Option C - Opinion of 2 doctors: While seeking the opinion of two doctors is an important aspect of medical decision-making, it alone is not sufficient. Consent from the pregnant woman (mother) is crucial, as she holds the right to make decisions about her own body and pregnancy. The involvement of the woman's consent in addition to medical opinions is necessary.

Option D - All above: The correct answer is option b, which involves the consent of the pregnant woman along with the opinion of two doctors. The other options either miss important elements (a, c) or include unnecessary elements (d).

questions.text: Which manoeuvre is performed when the fetal scalp is visible at the vulva as Shown in the image below
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ritgen Maneuver:

  • The Ritgen maneuver is performed when the fetal scalp becomes visible at the vulva during the second stage of labor. This maneuver involves applying gentle upward pressure to the fetal head while simultaneously flexing the head slightly towards the maternal symphysis pubis. The goal of the Ritgen maneuver is to prevent excessive extension of the fetal head, protect the perineum, and promote controlled delivery of the baby's head while minimizing the risk of perineal tears.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Loveset’s maneuver: Løvset's Maneuver involves rotation of the trunk of the foetus during a breech birth to facilitate delivery of the extended foetal arms and the shoulders

Option C - Pinard Maneuver: The Pinard manoeuvre in accomplished by inserting two fingers along one extremity to the knee, which is then pushed away from the midline (abducted) at the same time as flexing the leg at the hip. This causes spontaneous flexion of the knee and delivery of the foot.

Option D - Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit Maneuver: The Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit maneuver is a technique used to assist with the delivery of a baby's head during childbirth. It involves applying gentle downward traction on the baby's head while simultaneously flexing the head to facilitate its passage through the birth canal. This maneuver is used when the baby's head is delivered to the perineum and needs assistance to complete the delivery.

questions.text: Just after delivery, the position of the uterus corresponds to the level of how many weeks?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 20 weeks:

  • Just after delivery, the uterus is typically positioned at the level of about 20 weeks of pregnancy. This is because the uterus needs time to contract and shrink back to its normal size. It takes a few weeks for the uterus to descend into the pelvis and resume its non-pregnant position.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 16 weeks: The uterus at this stage of 16 weeks would be higher and larger during pregnancy than immediately after delivery.

Option C - 12 weeks: The uterus at 12 weeks of pregnancy would still be higher and larger than immediately after delivery.

Option D - 28 weeks: At 28 weeks of pregnancy, the uterus would be larger and positioned higher in the abdomen than just after delivery.

questions.text: A primigravida with severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding presents to the ER at 32 weeks. On examination uterus is tender and fetus was not palpable. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Abruptio placenta:

  • Abruptio placenta, also known as placental abruption, is a condition where the placenta prematurely separates from the uterine wall before the baby is delivered. This can lead to severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding, which are common symptoms of abruptio placenta. The tenderness of the uterus and the fact that the fetus is not palpable could be indicative of a retroplacental clot forming due to the separation of the placenta. This condition can be life-threatening for both the mother and the fetus, requiring prompt medical intervention.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Placenta previa: Placenta previa involves the placenta covering part or all of the cervix, which can lead to painless vaginal bleeding. It usually doesn't cause severe abdominal pain or tenderness of the uterus.

Option C - Rupture uterus: Ruptured uterus would typically present with sudden, severe abdominal pain, and there would likely be signs of shock. In this case, the uterus might not be tender, and the fetus might not be palpable due to being outside the uterus.

Option D - Polyhydramnios: Polyhydramnios, or excessive amniotic fluid, doesn't usually present with severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. It might cause discomfort, but it wouldn't be the primary diagnosis in this scenario.

questions.text: Which among the following is an outlet forcep?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Wrigley Forceps:

  • Wrigley forceps are a type of obstetrical forceps used in childbirth. They are designed to grasp the fetal head and assist in its delivery during complicated labor or when there's a need for intervention. These forceps have a distinctive S-shaped curve and are utilized to provide controlled traction and rotation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Piper Forceps: The Piper forceps are made expressly for stabilizing and delivering the aftercoming head in a breech presentation with to their lengthy, backward-curving shanks and reverse pelvic curve.

Option C - Kielland's Forceps: Kielland's forceps are another type of obstetrical forceps. They have a curved shape with fenestrations (openings) at the tips to accommodate the fetal head. These forceps are used to assist in rotating the baby's head into the proper position for delivery in cases of fetal malposition.

Option D - Das Forceps: For use in the delivery of babies born to Indian mothers, who often have a narrower pelvis and newborn with a lower birth weight, Das created a lighter and shorter variant of long curved obstetric forceps.

questions.text: Suction and evacuation is best done at?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 12 weeks:

  • This is a commonly cited timeframe for early pregnancy termination procedures. Suction and evacuation, often referred to as suction aspiration or vacuum aspiration, can typically be performed safely up to around 12 weeks of gestation. The procedure involves using suction to remove the embryo or fetus from the uterus. It's considered a relatively safe and effective method during this early stage of pregnancy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 15 weeks: Suction and evacuation can still be a viable option up to around 15 weeks of pregnancy, though the appropriateness of this timeframe might depend on specific medical factors and local regulations. As the pregnancy progresses, the procedure becomes more complex and the risks may increase. Medical professionals will evaluate the individual's health and medical history to determine the best course of action.

Option C - 6 weeks: Suction and evacuation are less commonly performed at such an early stage of pregnancy. At 6 weeks, a medication abortion using pills (such as mifepristone and misoprostol) is often considered as an alternative to surgical methods. This involves taking medication to induce a miscarriage. However, the specific medical guidelines can vary, and it's important to consult a healthcare provider for appropriate advice.

Option D - 18 weeks: Suction and evacuation might be an option up to 18 weeks of pregnancy, but it's generally considered a more advanced stage for this procedure. As the pregnancy progresses, the complexity and potential risks increase. At this stage, the method used and the specific medical considerations will vary based on individual circumstances and local regulations.

questions.text: A 32 year old female presents on 5th postnatal day, with complaints of low mood and mild depressive symptoms that are transient and self-limited. The depressive symptoms include sadness, crying, exhaustion, irritability, anxiety, decreased sleep, decreased concentration, and labile mood. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Postpartum blues:

  • Postpartum blues, also known as "baby blues," are transient and mild mood disturbances that occur within the first few days after childbirth. The symptoms typically include feelings of sadness, crying, irritability, anxiety, and mood lability. These symptoms are self-limited and usually resolve on their own without treatment within a couple of weeks. This is the most likely diagnosis given the transient and self-limited nature of the symptoms described in the scenario.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Postpartum psychosis: Postpartum psychosis is a severe and rare condition that involves a rapid onset of symptoms such as hallucinations, delusions, confusion, and disorganized behavior. It is a psychiatric emergency and requires immediate medical attention. The symptoms described in the scenario do not match the severe and acute nature of postpartum psychosis.

Option C - Postpartum depression: Postpartum depression is a more prolonged and severe mood disorder that occurs within the first year after childbirth. The symptoms include persistent feelings of sadness, loss of interest, fatigue, changes in sleep and appetite, difficulty concentrating, and even thoughts of self-harm or harming the baby. While some of the symptoms in the scenario overlap with postpartum depression, the transient and self-limited nature of the symptoms make postpartum blues a more likely diagnosis.

Option D - Postpartum hemorrhage: Postpartum hemorrhage refers to excessive bleeding after childbirth, and it is a medical complication related to physical health rather than mood symptoms. It is not relevant to the symptoms described in the scenario.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of the image given below ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Option D - Anencephaly Craniorachischisis: Craniorachischisis is a severe neural tube defect where there is an open neural tube from the brain to the spine. It is a more severe form of neural tube defect than spina bifida, and it involves the entire length of the neural tube.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Microcephaly: Microcephaly is a medical condition characterized by a smaller than average head size in comparison to infants of the same age and sex. It is diagnosed when the head circumference is significantly below the normal range for a child's age and sex. Microcephaly can be present at birth or it may develop in the early years of life.
