  • Rupture in the fimbriae (option b), ampulla (option c), or isthmus (option d) of the fallopian tube is less common in late-stage tubal pregnancies. The fimbriae and isthmus are not as susceptible to late rupture because they have more capacity to expand and accommodate the growing pregnancy.

While late rupture is relatively less common overall, when it does occur, it is more likely to happen in the interstitial portion of the fallopian tube due to its anatomical characteristics.

questions.text: A lady during labor presented with persistent occiput posterior position. Manual rotation was tried but it was unsuccessful. What is the pelvis type?
questions.solution:
Correct option B: Android

  • The android pelvis is characterized by a heart-shaped or triangular inlet, narrow anteroposterior diameter, and prominent sacral promontory.
  • This type of pelvis is less favorable for childbirth and is associated with a higher incidence of fetal malpositions, including occiput posterior position.
  • Occiput posterior position refers to the position of the baby's head facing towards the mother's sacrum during labor, which can result in prolonged labor and increased risk of complications such as prolonged second stage of labor, fetal distress, and instrumental delivery.

Incorrect options

Option A: Gynecoid

  • The gynecoid pelvis is considered the most favorable type for childbirth. It is characterized by a round or oval-shaped inlet, adequate anteroposterior diameter, and gently curved sacrum. Occiput posterior position is less common in the gynecoid pelvis.

Option C: Osteomalatic pelvis

  •  Osteomalatic pelvis refers to a pelvis affected by osteomalacia, which can lead to structural changes in the pelvis but is not specifically associated with persistent occiput posterior position during labor.

Option D: Platypelloid

  • The platypelloid pelvis is characterized by a transversely wide and flat pelvic inlet, which is less common and less favorable for childbirth. However, persistent occiput posterior position during labor is more commonly associated with the android pelvis than the platypelloid pelvis.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed autosomal aneuploidy that leads to spontaneous abortions?
questions.solution:
Correct option  A. 

  • Trisomy 16 is the most commonly observed autosomal aneuploidy leading to spontaneous abortions, also known as miscarriages. Aneuploidy refers to an abnormal number of chromosomes, where there is an extra or missing chromosome. In the case of trisomy 16, there is an extra copy of chromosome 16. This condition is often incompatible with life, and most pregnancies affected by trisomy 16 result in early miscarriages.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Trisomy 20: Trisomy 20 is relatively rare compared to Trisomy 16 as a cause of spontaneous abortions. Trisomy 20 does occur, but it is not the most commonly observed autosomal aneuploidy leading to miscarriages.

Option C. Monosomy refers to the presence of only one copy of a particular chromosome instead of the usual two. While monosomy can lead to developmental issues and pregnancy loss, it is not the most commonly observed autosomal aneuploidy leading to spontaneous abortions.

Option D. Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome) is a chromosomal disorder where there is an extra copy of chromosome 18. It is associated with severe developmental abnormalities and is a cause of spontaneous abortions, but it is not the most commonly observed autosomal aneuploidy leading to spontaneous abortions

questions.text: A 19-year-old primigravida female, presents with 8 weeks of amenorrhea, light PV bleeding and pain in abdomen. O/E Her Uterine size corresponds to POG and Os is closed. USG reveals single live intrauterine pregnancy. What is preferred management in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option . C.

  • In a 19-year-old primigravida with 8 weeks of amenorrhea, light bleeding, closed cervical os, and a single live intrauterine pregnancy detected on ultrasound (USG), the preferred management is bed rest and progesterone therapy.
  • This is likely a threatened miscarriage, where there is vaginal bleeding but the cervix is closed and the pregnancy is viable.
  • Bed rest helps reduce physical activity and stress on the uterus, while progesterone supplementation supports the endometrium and pregnancy.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Estrogen plus Progesterone therapy is not the preferred management in this case, as estrogen supplementation is not necessary and may not be beneficial.

Option B: Dilatation and Curettage (D&C) is not indicated in a case of threatened miscarriage with a closed cervix and a viable intrauterine pregnancy.

Option D: Beta hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) levels may be monitored serially to assess the progression of the pregnancy and rule out ectopic pregnancy, but it is not the preferred management in this scenario.

questions.text: Couvelaire uterus is seen in which of the following ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Abruptio placenta

  • Couvelaire uterus, also known as uteroplacental apoplexy or retroplacental hematoma, is a rare condition characterized by bleeding and blood infiltration into the myometrium (muscular layer of the uterus) following a severe placental abruption.
  • Placental abruption occurs when the placenta prematurely separates from the uterine wall before delivery, leading to significant maternal and fetal complications.
  • The blood infiltrates into the uterine muscle, resulting in a bluish discoloration of the uterus known as Couvelaire uterus.

Incorrect options:

Option A.Placenta previa: Placenta previa refers to a condition where the placenta partially or completely covers the cervix, but it is not related to Couvelaire uterus.

Option B. Vasa previa: Vasa previa is a condition where fetal blood vessels cross the cervix ahead of the baby, and they are at risk of rupture during labor. It is not associated with the Couvelaire uterus.

Option D. Placenta percreta: Placenta percreta is a severe form of placenta accreta, where the placenta invades and penetrates through the uterine wall. It is not directly associated with the Couvelaire uterus.

questions.text: How many times does a woman need to have given birth in order to be classified as a grand multipara?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: ≥5

  • A grand multipara refers to a woman who has given birth to five or more babies.
  • "grand multiparity" is a patient who has had ≥5 births (live or stillborn) at ≥20 weeks of gestation
  • The prefix "grand" signifies a higher number, indicating that the woman has had multiple pregnancies and deliveries.

  • This means that a woman needs to have given birth at least five times to be classified as a grand multipara. The other options are incorrect because they do not meet the criteria for the classification of a grand multipara:

Incorrect Options:

Option A:  ≥2: This would refer to a woman who has given birth more than two times but does not qualify as a grand multipara.

Option B: . ≥3: This would refer to a woman who has given birth more than three times but does not qualify as a grand multipara.

Option C: ≥4: This would refer to a woman who has given birth more than four times but does not meet the criteria for being classified as a grand multipara.

questions.text: A case of a 26-weeks pregnant woman, exhibited hypertension for the first time, without any presence of proteinuria. What is the medical examination aimed to determine the diagnosis for this particular condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option : C. 

  • In this scenario, the diagnosis would be Gestational Hypertension.
  • Gestational hypertension refers to the development of high blood pressure (hypertension) after 20 weeks of pregnancy in a previously normotensive woman.
  • It is characterized by elevated blood pressure without the presence of proteinuria (protein in the urine), which is a distinguishing factor from preeclampsia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Chronic hypertension: Chronic hypertension refers to pre-existing high blood pressure that predates the pregnancy or is diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation.

Option B. Eclampsia: Eclampsia is a severe complication of preeclampsia characterized by seizures in a pregnant woman with hypertension and proteinuria.

Option D. Preeclampsia: Preeclampsia is a condition of pregnancy characterized by high blood pressure and significant proteinuria, among other symptoms. In this scenario, proteinuria is not present, making it more consistent with gestational hypertension.

questions.text: A patient who was using CuT for contraception, presented with a 20 weeks of gestation. The IUD is placed at fundus, tail visible at OS and she wants to continue the pregnancy. What is your next step in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C

  • The next step in this scenario would be to remove the intrauterine contraceptive device (IUD) and allow the patient to continue the pregnancy.
  • If an IUD is found in the uterus during pregnancy, it is generally recommended to remove it to reduce the risk of complications such as infection, preterm labor, or fetal injury.
  • Once the IUD is safely removed, the patient can continue with prenatal care and the pregnancy can progress normally.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Leave IUD in-situ, continue pregnancy: This option is incorrect because leaving the IUD in place during pregnancy can pose risks such as infection, preterm labor, or injury to the fetus.

Option B. Do medical termination of Pregnancy: This option is incorrect because there is no indication for termination of pregnancy solely based on the presence of the IUD. If the patient desires to continue the pregnancy and the IUD can be safely removed, termination would not be necessary.

Option D. Remove IUCD and do MTP: This option is incorrect because it suggests termination of pregnancy (MTP) even though the patient wants to continue the pregnancy. Removal of the IUD alone, without the need for termination, is the appropriate course of action in this case.

questions.text: What could be a potential etiology for Oligohydramnios?
questions.solution:
Correct Option . C

  • Renal agenesis, the absence of one or both kidneys, can be a cause of oligohydramnios.
  • Amniotic fluid is primarily composed of fetal urine, and the kidneys play a crucial role in its production. In cases of renal agenesis, the absence or underdevelopment of the kidneys can lead to a reduction in amniotic fluid volume.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Multiparity: Multiparity, which refers to a history of multiple pregnancies, is not a direct cause of oligohydramnios.

Option B. Twins: While twin pregnancies can sometimes be associated with lower amniotic fluid levels, it is not a specific cause of oligohydramnios. The fluid levels in a twin pregnancy can vary depending on various factors.

Option D. Macrosomia: Macrosomia, which refers to a large baby, is not a direct cause of oligohydramnios. Oligohydramnios is primarily related to factors affecting amniotic fluid production or retention rather than fetal size.

questions.text: During pregnancy, during which trimester is acute fatty liver most commonly observed?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C:Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) is a rare but serious condition that can occur during pregnancy. It typically manifests most commonly in the third trimester, although it can occur in the second trimester as well. The condition is characterized by the accumulation of fat in the liver, leading to liver dysfunction and potential complications for both the mother and the baby.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A: First trimester: AFLP is not commonly seen in the first trimester of pregnancy. While liver-related complications can occur during pregnancy, AFLP specifically tends to manifest most commonly in the later stages of pregnancy, particularly the third trimester.

Option B: Second trimester: Although AFLP is less common in the second trimester compared to the third trimester, it can still occur during this period. However, the third trimester is the time when AFLP is most commonly observed. The second trimester is generally considered a relatively low-risk period for AFLP compared to the later stages of pregnancy.

Option D: Both a and b: This option suggests that acute fatty liver (AFLP) can manifest most commonly during both the first and second trimesters of pregnancy. However, this is not accurate.

questions.text: What is correct regarding alterations in the vagina during a typical pregnancy?

choices.text: Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B) Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium:

This statement is true. The hormonal changes during pregnancy, particularly the increased levels of estrogen, promote glycogen production in the vaginal epithelial cells. Glycogen serves as a source of nutrients for Lactobacilli, helping them to maintain a healthy vaginal environment.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A) Decreased number of Lactobacilli: This statement is incorrect. Lactobacilli are the dominant bacteria found in a healthy vagina, and they play a crucial role in maintaining a slightly acidic pH and preventing the overgrowth of harmful bacteria. During pregnancy, the number of Lactobacilli tends to remain stable or may even increase.

Option C) pH > 6.8: This statement is incorrect. In a normal pregnancy, the vaginal pH remains acidic, typically below 4.5, rather than becoming alkaline or having a pH greater than 6.8. The presence of Lactobacilli, which produces lactic acid, helps maintain the acidic pH of the vagina and provides a protective barrier against potential infections.

Option D) Epithelial thinning: This statement is incorrect. In a normal pregnancy, the vaginal epithelium undergoes certain changes to adapt to hormonal fluctuations, but it does not thin out. The increased estrogen levels during pregnancy can cause the vaginal epithelium to become thicker, more pliable, and better vascularized.

questions.text: During a routine ultrasound scan at 16 weeks, you identify indications of cardiac malformation in a fetus. At what fasting blood sugar level would you begin to suspect overt diabetes?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B: 126 mg/dL: A fasting blood sugar level of 126 mg/dL or higher is the generally accepted threshold for suspecting overt diabetes. If a person's fasting blood sugar level consistently meets or exceeds this value on two separate occasions, it may indicate the presence of diabetes.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A) 106 mg/dL: A fasting blood sugar level of 106 mg/dL is not typically considered the minimum level at which overt diabetes can be suspected. The diagnostic threshold for diabetes is generally set at 126 mg/dL or higher, as mentioned earlier.

Option C) 116 mg/dL: A fasting blood sugar level of 116 mg/dL is not commonly used as the threshold for suspecting overt diabetes. The diagnostic criterion typically requires a level of 126 mg/dL or higher.

Option D) 130 mg/dL: A fasting blood sugar level of 130 mg/dL is also not typically used as the minimum level at which overt diabetes can be suspected. The diagnostic threshold is generally set at 126 mg/dL or higher.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options experiences a decrease during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C: Functional residual capacity:.Functional residual capacity (FRC), decreases during pregnancy. As the uterus expands, it elevates the diaphragm, leading to reduced lung expansion and decreased FRC. This reduction in FRC is primarily due to the displacement of the diaphragm by the growing uterus.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A) Respiratory rate:.Respiratory rate,typically remains unchanged or may slightly increase during pregnancy.

Option B) Vital capacity: Vital capacity, which represents the maximum amount of air a person can exhale after a maximal inhalation, generally increases during pregnancy. The growing uterus pushes upward, which allows for greater expansion of the chest and lungs, resulting in increased vital capacity.
Option D) Inspiratory capacity: Inspiratory capacity, representing the maximum volume of air a person can inhale after a normal exhalation, typically increases during pregnancy. The increased chest and lung expansion allows for greater inspiratory capacity.

questions.text: Which of the following does not pose a contraindication for the initiation of labor?

choices.text: History of lower transverse cesarean section in last two pregnancies

questions.solution:
Correct Option :

Option C) Intrauterine Growth Restriction : Intrauterine Growth Restriction is not a contraindication for the induction of labor. However, it is important to consider the specific type and severity of Intrauterine Growth Restriction, as well as the overall health status of the mother. In some cases, certain heart conditions may require special monitoring and management during labor and delivery.
​​​​​​​

Incorrect options :

Option A) Pelvic tumor: A pelvic tumor can be a contraindication for the induction of labor, depending on the size, location, and nature of the tumor. The presence of a large pelvic tumor may obstruct the birth canal and make a vaginal delivery difficult or impossible. In such cases, a cesarean section may be recommended.

Option B) Herpes infection: Active genital herpes infection, particularly during labor, can pose a risk of transmitting the virus to the newborn. In such cases, if there are active lesions or symptoms of herpes, a cesarean section may be recommended to reduce the risk of transmission.


Option D) History of lower transverse cesarean section in the last two pregnancies: A history of lower transverse cesarean section in previous pregnancies does not necessarily contraindicate the induction of labor. The decision to induce labor in subsequent pregnancies after a previous cesarean section would depend on various factors, such as the reason for the previous cesarean, the presence of any complications or risks, and the overall health of the mother and baby.

questions.text: What is the grade of placenta previa depicted in the provided image?
questions.solution:
Correct option : 

Option B: The given image shows grade 3 placenta previa. Grade 3 placenta previa is characterized by the placenta partially covering the opening of theInternal os. It means that the edge of the placenta reaches but does not completely cover theInternal os.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A) Option A: IV (Grade 4) - Grade 4 placenta previa is characterized by complete coverage of the opening of the internal os by the placenta.

Option C) Option C: II (Grade 2) - Grade 2 placenta previa is characterized by the placenta reaching the Internal os but not covering the opening.


Option D) Option D: I (Grade 1) - Grade 1 placenta previa indicates that the placenta is located in the lower part of the uterus but does not reach or cover the internal os.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a normal physiological change during pregnancy?

choices.text: Mild ST changes in inferior leads

questions.solution:
Correct option: 

Option D) Pansystolic murmur: Pansystolic murmur is not a normal physiological change in pregnancy. A pansystolic murmur, also known as a holosystolic murmur, is typically indicative of abnormal blood flow or structural abnormalities in the heart valves, such as mitral regurgitation or tricuspid regurgitation.

 

Incorrect options :

Option A) Left axis deviation: Left axis deviation can be a normal physiological change in pregnancy due to the upward displacement of the diaphragm caused by the growing uterus. However, it is essential to rule out any underlying cardiac conditions if left axis deviation is present.

Option B) Mild ST changes in inferior leads: Mild ST changes, such as slight ST segment depression or T-wave inversion, can be normal findings in the inferior leads of the electrocardiogram (ECG) during pregnancy. These changes are believed to be related to hemodynamic and hormonal alterations in pregnancy.
Option C) Atrial and ventricular premature contractions: Atrial and ventricular premature contractions, which represent irregular heartbeats originating from the atria or ventricles, can be normal physiological changes in pregnancy. These premature contractions are often associated with the increased blood volume and hormonal changes during pregnancy. However, it is important to differentiate them from more significant or frequent premature contractions that may indicate an underlying cardiac condition.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a pregnant woman at 28 weeks of gestation, who has a fibroid uterus and is experiencing intense abdominal pain, but no fever, with a WBC count of 8000 cells/ul?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for a pregnant woman at 28 weeks of gestation, experiencing intense abdominal pain, with a fibroid uterus, but no fever and a normal WBC count, could be:

Option A. Red degeneration of fibroid

Explanation:

Option A. Red degeneration of fibroid: Correct. Red degeneration of a fibroid occurs due to inadequate blood supply, leading to hemorrhage and necrosis within the fibroid tissue. It can cause severe abdominal pain, especially during pregnancy when fibroids may undergo changes due to increased vascularity. This condition does not typically cause fever or elevated white blood cell count.

Option B. Preterm labor: Less likely. Preterm labor can cause abdominal pain during pregnancy, but it is not directly related to the presence of a fibroid. Preterm labor can be associated with uterine contractions, back pain, and a change in vaginal discharge.

Option C. Torsion of fibroid: Less likely. Torsion of a fibroid, where the fibroid twists on its pedicle, can cause severe pain. However, this is a relatively rare event. Torsion of a fibroid can lead to ischemia and necrosis, causing intense pain. It may or may not be associated with fever, depending on the presence of infection.

Option D. None of the above: Red degeneration of fibroid is a possible diagnosis based on the symptoms described.

questions.text: In the management of mastitis in a breastfeeding mother, what is the initial treatment approach?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A) Dicloxacillin: Dicloxacillin, a penicillinase-resistant penicillin, is a commonly used first-line antibiotic for the treatment of mastitis in lactating mothers. It is effective against Staphylococcus aureus, including methicillin-resistant strains (MRSA), which are the most common causative organisms of mastitis.

 

Incorrect options:

Option B) Cefazolin: Cefazolin is a cephalosporin antibiotic that may have activity against the bacteria involved in mastitis, including Staphylococcus aureus. However, penicillinase-resistant penicillins, such as dicloxacillin, are generally preferred as the first-line treatment for mastitis.

 

Option C) Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is another cephalosporin antibiotic that may have activity against the bacteria involved in mastitis. However, it is not typically recommended as the first-line treatment for mastitis in lactating mothers. Penicillinase-resistant penicillins, such as dicloxacillin, are generally preferred.


OptionD) Ampicillin: Ampicillin is a broad-spectrum penicillin antibiotic. While it may have some activity against the bacteria involved in mastitis, it is not specifically indicated as the first-line treatment. Penicillinase-resistant penicillins, such as dicloxacillin, are generally preferred due to their efficacy against Staphylococcus aureus and MRSA strains commonly associated with mastitis.

questions.text: What is the primary source of amniotic fluid after 20 weeks of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A) Fetal urine:

After 20 weeks of gestation, the major contributor to the amniotic fluid volume is fetal urine. The fetus produces urine as a byproduct of its metabolic processes. The urine is then excreted into the amniotic sac, contributing to the overall volume of amniotic fluid.

 

Incorrect options:

 

Option B) Fetal skin: While fetal skin does contribute to the production of amniotic fluid through the shedding of cells, it is not the major contributor post 20 weeks. Fetal urine is the primary source of amniotic fluid at this stage.

 

Option C) Fetal lung fluid: Fetal lung fluid, also known as pulmonary fluid or lung secretions, is produced by the fetal lungs. It is present in the amniotic sac before the 20th week of gestation and plays a crucial role in lung development. However, after 20 weeks, fetal urine becomes the primary source of amniotic fluid.


OptionD) Maternal plasma: Maternal plasma refers to the fluid component of the mother's blood. While maternal plasma can contribute to the amniotic fluid volume to some extent, it is not the major contributor post 20 weeks. Fetal urine surpasses the contribution of maternal plasma in maintaining amniotic fluid levels.

questions.text: What is the highest dosage of PGF2 alpha recommended for treating postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B) 2 mg

Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) is a significant cause of maternal morbidity and mortality. Prostaglandin F2 alpha (PGF2 alpha) is one of the medications used to manage PPH by promoting uterine contraction and reducing bleeding.

The maximum recommended dose of PGF2 alpha for postpartum hemorrhage is 2 mg. This dose is typically administered either intramuscularly or intravenously, depending on the clinical situation.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A) 0.25 mg: This dose is much lower than the maximum recommended dose for PGF2 alpha in postpartum hemorrhage. It may not provide the desired therapeutic effect in managing significant bleeding.

 

Option C) 20 mg: This dose is excessively high and exceeds the maximum recommended dose for PGF2 alpha in postpartum hemorrhage. Such a high dose can lead to adverse effects and complications.


OptionD) 200 mg: Similarly, this dose is extremely high and far beyond the maximum recommended dose for PGF2 alpha in postpartum hemorrhage. Administering such a high dose can be dangerous and increase the risk of adverse reactions.

questions.text: What is the condition of the mother if the baby's appearance indicates that it was born at 34 weeks of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct option :

Option A) Gestational diabetes:

Gestational diabetes is a condition characterized by high blood sugar levels that develop during pregnancy. It occurs when the body is unable to produce enough insulin to meet the increased demands of pregnancy. If gestational diabetes is not well controlled, it can result in the baby growing larger than expected for their gestational age, a condition known as macrosomia.

 

Incorrect options:

Option B) Rubella: Rubella, also known as German measles, is a viral infection that can cause various birth defects if a pregnant woman becomes infected during pregnancy. However, the appearance of the baby alone cannot definitively indicate that the mother has rubella.

 

Option C) Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism refers to an underactive thyroid gland, which can affect the mother's health during pregnancy. While hypothyroidism can lead to certain complications in the baby, such as low birth weight or developmental issues, it typically does not result in a baby being large for gestational age.


OptionD) Gestational hypertension: Gestational hypertension refers to high blood pressure that develops during pregnancy. While gestational hypertension can lead to complications for both the mother and the baby, it does not directly cause the baby to be large for gestational age.

questions.text: When is the optimal period to assess nuchal translucency?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B: 11-14 weeks : Nuchal translucency (NT) evaluation is a prenatal screening test used to assess the risk of certain chromosomal abnormalities, particularly Down syndrome (trisomy 21). The ideal time for NT evaluation is between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation.

 

During this time, the fetus is at a specific stage of development where the nuchal translucency, which is the fluid-filled space at the back of the fetal neck, can be accurately measured. This measurement, along with other factors like maternal age and blood test results, is used to calculate the risk of chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A: 6-8 weeks: It is too early for accurate NT evaluation as the fetal structures necessary for the measurement are not fully developed.

Option C: 14-16 weeks : It is beyond the optimal time frame for NT evaluation. While some additional ultrasound assessments can be performed during this period, the NT measurement is typically done earlier.
Option D: 16-20 weeks: It is outside the recommended time frame for NT evaluation. At this stage, other ultrasound assessments, such as the detailed anatomy scan, are performed, but NT evaluation is not typically included.

questions.text: Magnesium sulphate has no role in which of the following ?

choices.text: Prevention of seizures in severe pre-eclampsia
Prevention of recurrent seizures in eclampsia

questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Prevention of RDS (Respiratory Distress Syndrome) in premature babies :

  • Magnesium sulfate does not have a direct role in preventing or treating RDS in premature infants.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Prevention of seizures in severe pre-eclampsia: Magnesium sulfate is commonly used as a first-line treatment for preventing seizures in pregnant women with severe pre-eclampsia.

Option B- Prevention of recurrent seizures in eclampsia: Magnesium sulfate is also used for the prevention of recurrent seizures in women who have already experienced eclampsia. It helps control and prevent further seizures, improving the safety and well-being of both the mother and the baby.

Option D- Reducing contractility of the uterus: Magnesium sulfate is also used as a tocolytic agent to reduce the contractility of the uterus. It is sometimes administered to pregnant women experiencing preterm labor to delay delivery and allow for the administration of corticosteroids to improve fetal lung maturity.

questions.text: In the vertex presentation with complete flexion attitude of the head, which of the following is observed?
questions.solution:
Correct option: Option A: Suboccipito-bregmatic diameter: In a vertex presentation with complete flexion of the head, the fetal head is in a position where the chin is touching or close to the chest. This position allows for the smallest diameter of the fetal head, known as the suboccipito-bregmatic diameter, to be presented at the maternal pelvic inlet.

 

Incorrect options:

Option B. Suboccipito-frontal diameter: This diameter refers to the distance between the suboccipital point (back of the head) and the forehead. It is not specifically associated with the complete flexion of the head seen in vertex presentations.

 

Option C. Occipito-frontal diameter: This diameter measures the distance between the occiput (back of the head) and the forehead. It is larger than the suboccipito-bregmatic diameter and is not specifically associated with complete flexion of the head.


Option  D. Occipito-posterior position: This term refers to a fetal position in which the back of the head (occiput) is facing the mother's back, which is also known as the "sunny side up" position. It is not directly related to the flexion attitude of the head.

questions.text: What is the most suitable treatment option for a pregnant woman who has a history of multiple miscarriages and has been recently diagnosed with antiphospholipid antibody syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct option B: Aspirin + Heparin

This combination is the recommended treatment for pregnant women with antiphospholipid syndrome and a history of recurrent abortions. Aspirin helps prevent platelet aggregation and improve blood flow, while heparin, specifically low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), has anticoagulant effects and helps prevent blood clots. Together, aspirin and heparin have been shown to reduce the risk of recurrent abortions and improve pregnancy outcomes in women with antiphospholipid syndrome.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A. Aspirin only: Aspirin alone is not sufficient for the treatment of antiphospholipid syndrome in pregnancy. While aspirin has antiplatelet effects and can help improve blood flow, it is not enough to prevent the complications associated with antiphospholipid syndrome.

 

Option C. Heparin + Steroids: Steroids are usually reserved for specific situations where there is a high risk of complications, such as severe placental insufficiency or intrauterine growth restriction. But Aspirin helps prevent platelet aggregation and improve blood flow.


OptionD. Aspirin + Steroids: Similar to the previous option, the combination of aspirin and steroids alone is not considered the best mode of treatment for antiphospholipid syndrome in pregnancy. Steroids may have a role in certain high-risk cases, but they are not the primary treatment modality.

questions.text: During pregnancy, in which trimester does acute fatty liver typically present most frequently?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Third trimester

  • Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) typically manifests most commonly in the third trimester of pregnancy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- First trimester: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) is extremely rare in the first trimester. It is primarily a third-trimester condition, although it can occur in the second trimester as well.

Option B- Second trimester: AFLP is less commonly seen in the second trimester compared to the third trimester. While it is possible for AFLP to manifest during the second trimester, it is not the most common period for its occurrence.

Option D- Both A and B: This option is incorrect because AFLP is most commonly seen in the third trimester, and while it can occur in the second trimester, it is less frequent.

questions.text: Which of the following ligament is responsible for maintaining the anteversion of the uterus during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Round ligament

  • During pregnancy, the round ligament plays a crucial role in maintaining the anteversion of the uterus.
  • The round ligament is a band of fibrous tissue that originates from the upper part of the uterus near the fallopian tubes and extends through the inguinal canal to attach to the labia majora.
  • It helps to support the uterus and keep it in an anteverted (forward-tilted) position.
  • As the uterus grows and expands during pregnancy, the round ligament stretches and allows the uterus to expand while maintaining its anteverted position.
  • This helps to support the growing fetus and maintain the proper alignment of the uterus within the pelvis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B- Cardinal ligament: The cardinal ligament provides important support to the cervix and upper part of the vagina. It helps to hold the uterus in place and plays a role in maintaining its stability. However, it is not specifically responsible for maintaining the anteversion of the uterus during pregnancy.

Option C- Uterosacral ligament: The uterosacral ligament provides support to the uterus and helps to anchor it to the sacrum (lower part of the spine). It is involved in maintaining the position and stability of the uterus but is not primarily responsible for maintaining anteversion during pregnancy.

Option D- Pubocervical ligament: The pubocervical ligament provides support to the cervix and connects it to the pubic bone. It helps to maintain the position and stability of the cervix but does not play a significant role in maintaining anteversion of the uterus during pregnancy.

questions.text: Quadruple testing is done during which of the following weeks of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: 15-20 weeks

  • 15-20 weeks - This option is correct. The quadruple test, also known as the quadruple marker or quadruple screen, is typically done between 15-20 weeks of pregnancy.
  • It involves a blood test to measure the levels of four substances: alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), unconjugated estriol (uE3), and inhibin A.
  • These markers help in assessing the risk of certain chromosomal abnormalities, neural tube defects, and other fetal conditions.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- 9-11 weeks: This option is incorrect. During the 9-11 week period of pregnancy, a different test called the nuchal translucency (NT) scan is typically performed. The NT scan is used to assess the risk of certain chromosomal abnormalities, particularly Down syndrome. It involves measuring the thickness of the fluid-filled space at the back of the baby's neck.

Option B- 12-14 weeks: This option is also incorrect. In the 12-14 week period, a combination of tests called the first-trimester screening is typically conducted. The first-trimester screening involves a blood test to measure specific hormones and proteins, along with the NT scan. These tests are used to assess the risk of chromosomal abnormalities.

Option D- 22-28 weeks: This option is incorrect. During the 22-28 week period, a glucose tolerance test (GTT) is usually performed to screen for gestational diabetes. The GTT measures blood sugar levels after consuming a glucose solution.

questions.text: What is the recommended frequency of antenatal visits?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: 12-14

  • The ideal number of antenatal visits recommended by healthcare professionals is typically between 12 and 14 visits. These visits allow healthcare providers to monitor the health of the mother and baby, perform necessary screenings and tests, provide prenatal education and counseling, and address any concerns or complications that may arise during the pregnancy.

Incorrect options

Option B- 6-8: Having only 6-8 antenatal visits would be inadequate for most pregnancies.

Option C- 7-9: While slightly closer to the correct answer, 7-9 antenatal visits would still be considered insufficient for most pregnancies.

Option D- 10-11: Although closer to the correct answer than the previous options, 10-11 antenatal visits would still be considered insufficient.

questions.text: What is the recommended course of action for managing a pregnant woman who tests positive for HIV during her first trimester?

choices.text: Start ART immediately and continue till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue life-long
Start ART immediately and continue life-long
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue till 6 weeks after delivery

questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Start ART immediately and continue life-long

  • Start ART immediately and continue life-long - This option is the correct management for a woman diagnosed with HIV in her first trimester.
  • Initiating ART immediately after diagnosis is essential to suppress the virus, reduce the viral load, and minimize the risk of transmitting HIV to the fetus.
  • Continuing ART life-long is necessary to maintain viral suppression, preserve the mother's health, and prevent transmission to sexual partners.

Incorrect Options

Option A- Start ART immediately and continue till 6 weeks after delivery: This option is not the most appropriate management for a pregnant woman diagnosed with HIV in her first trimester. While initiating ART immediately is important to suppress the HIV virus and prevent transmission to the fetus, discontinuing treatment after 6 weeks post-delivery would leave the woman at risk of disease progression and complications.

Option B- Start ART after the 1st trimester and continue life-long: This option is also not the most appropriate management. Delaying the initiation of ART until after the 1st trimester can increase the risk of transmission of HIV to the fetus during the early stages of pregnancy. The recommended approach is to start ART as soon as possible after diagnosis, regardless of the trimester.

Option D- Start ART after the 1st trimester and continue till 6 weeks after delivery: This option is not the most appropriate management. As mentioned earlier, delaying ART initiation until after the 1st trimester increases the risk of transmission to the fetus during the early stages of pregnancy. Moreover, discontinuing treatment after 6 weeks post-delivery leaves the woman at risk of disease progression.

questions.text: A pregnant women presents with obstructed labor and is grossly dehydrated. Investigations reveal fetal demise. What will be the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Cesarean section

  • Cesarean section: This is the appropriate management for a pregnant woman presenting with obstructed labor and fetal demise.
  • In cases of fetal demise, where the baby has died in the uterus,a cesarean section is performed to deliver the baby and provide necessary medical care to the mother.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Craniotomy- Craniotomy involves the surgical procedure of opening the skull. It is not an appropriate management option for obstructed labor with fetal demise. Craniotomy is occasionally performed in cases of severe fetal malformations or abnormalities where vaginal delivery is not feasible, but it is not the appropriate management in the given scenario.

Option B: Decapitation - Decapitation refers to the removal of the baby's head during childbirth. It is an extremely rare and extreme procedure performed only in very specific circumstances where vaginal delivery is impossible, and cesarean section is not feasible or safe. Decapitation is not a standard management option for obstructed labor with fetal demise.

Option D: Forceps extraction - Forceps extraction involves using specialized surgical instruments (forceps) to assist in the delivery of the baby's head during vaginal delivery. However, in the case of obstructed labor with fetal demise, forceps extraction may not be possible or appropriate.

questions.text: When is the most optimal period to determine the type of twin pregnancy using ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: 11-14 weeks

  • This is the best time to identify the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound.
  • During this scan, the sonographer can also assess the number of gestational sacs, placentas, and amniotic fluid levels, which helps determine the type of twin pregnancy.
  • Identifying the presence of two separate gestational sacs and placentas during this time indicates a dizygotic (fraternal) twin pregnancy, while a single gestational sac and placenta suggest a monozygotic (identical) twin pregnancy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: 18-22 weeks - While an ultrasound performed between 18-22 weeks can provide detailed information about fetal anatomy and development, it may not be the ideal time to accurately determine the type of twin pregnancy. By this stage, the anatomical features of the fetuses and their placentas may be more developed and distinguishable, but earlier ultrasound examinations, particularly in the first trimester, are typically more reliable in determining the type of twin pregnancy.

Option B: 24-28 weeks - Although an ultrasound performed between 24-28 weeks can provide valuable information about the growth and development of the fetuses, it is not the best time to identify the type of twin pregnancy. By this stage, the placentas and amniotic sacs may have undergone changes and may not be as clearly distinguishable as in earlier stages of pregnancy.

Option D: 14-18 weeks - While an ultrasound performed between 14-18 weeks can provide important information about fetal development, it may not be the optimal time to accurately determine the type of twin pregnancy. At this stage, the differentiation between monozygotic and dizygotic twins may not be as apparent, and the sonographer may not be able to visualize the necessary details for a definitive identification.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the umbilical cord is not true?

choices.text: It has one artery and two veins
It contains a gelatinous substance called Wharton's jelly
Presence of a single umbilical artery is associated with congenital anomalies
Normal average umbilical cord length is 50-60 cms

questions.solution:
Correct Option A: It has one artery and two veins

  • It has one artery and two veins - This statement is false.
  • The umbilical cord typically contains two umbilical artery and one umbilical vein.
  • The umbilical artery carries deoxygenated blood and waste products from the fetus to the placenta, while the umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood and nutrients from the placenta to the fetus.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: It contains a gelatinous substance called Wharton's jelly - This statement is true. The umbilical cord is composed of Wharton's jelly, a gelatinous substance that provides structural support and cushioning for the blood vessels within the cord. It helps to protect the vessels from compression and ensures efficient blood flow between the fetus and the placenta.

Option C: Presence of a single umbilical artery is associated with congenital anomalies - This statement is true. In some cases, the umbilical cord may have only one umbilical artery instead of the usual two. This condition, known as a single umbilical artery (SUA), is associated with a higher risk of certain congenital anomalies, such as heart defects, renal abnormalities, and chromosomal abnormalities. However, it is important to note that the presence of a single umbilical artery does not always indicate the presence of these anomalies, and further evaluation and testing may be required.

Option D: Normal average umbilical cord length is 50-60 cm - This statement is true. The normal average length of the umbilical cord is typically around 50-60 cm in the normal full term newborn.

questions.text: Which of the statements below is incorrect regarding non-invasive prenatal testing?

choices.text: It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum
It is used for the diagnosis of trisomy 13,18 and 21
It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation
It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment

questions.solution:
Option D. It is done after the routine first-trimester ultrasound assessment.

Explanation:

Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is a screening test that analyzes cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum to assess the risk of certain chromosomal abnormalities in the fetus. NIPT is typically performed after 10 weeks of gestation and can be done independently of the routine first-trimester ultrasound assessment. It is not directly related to the timing of the ultrasound. NIPT is commonly used to detect trisomy 13, 18, and 21 (Down syndrome) in the fetus.

questions.text: Which of the following does not contribute to the development of secondary primary postpartum hemorrhage(PPH)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Placenta previa

  • Placenta previa is a condition where the placenta partially or completely covers the cervix, leading to bleeding during pregnancy or delivery.
  • Placenta previa is a potential cause of primary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) due to antepartum bleeding but is not typically associated with secondary PPH, which refers to excessive bleeding occurring after the first 24 hours postpartum.

Incorrect Options

Option A: Retained cotyledon - Retained cotyledon refers to a portion of the placenta or fetal membranes that remains inside the uterus following childbirth. It can cause secondary PPH if not properly expelled, as it can lead to persistent bleeding and uterine atony (lack of uterine muscle tone).

Option B: Endometritis - Endometritis refers to inflammation or infection of the endometrium, the inner lining of the uterus. It can occur after delivery and can contribute to secondary PPH due to increased uterine activity and impaired uterine involution.

Option C: Placental polyp - A placental polyp is a rare condition where a piece of placental tissue remains attached to the uterine wall after delivery. It can lead to persistent bleeding and secondary PPH if not properly managed.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options is unable to pass through the placenta?  A. Iron  B. Albumin  C. Immunoglobulin M  D. Immunoglobulin G
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: B and C

  • Albumin: Albumin is a protein found in the blood. It is too large to cross the placenta, and therefore, it does not pass from the maternal bloodstream to the fetal circulation.
  • Immunoglobulin M (IgM): IgM is an antibody involved in the immune response. It is a large molecule and does not cross the placenta easily. Therefore, IgM antibodies present in the maternal bloodstream do not typically transfer to the fetal circulation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: This option in incorrect, as albumin is too large to cross the placenta,

Option B: This option in incorrect, as IgM is a large molecule and does not cross the placenta

Option D: this option in incorrect, as IgM is a large molecule and does not cross the placenta

questions.text: In which situations is dilatation and curettage considered inappropriate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Pelvic inflammatory disease

  • Dilatation and curettage (D&C) is contraindicated in the presence of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Ectopic pregnancy- D&C is not the preferred treatment for ectopic pregnancy. In cases of ectopic pregnancy, the primary management is typically through medication (methotrexate) or surgical intervention (laparoscopic surgery). D&C is not appropriate for treating ectopic pregnancy.

Option C: Menstrual irregularities- D&C can be used as a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure for certain types of menstrual irregularities, such as abnormal uterine bleeding or excessive tissue growth in the uterus (endometrial hyperplasia). However, it is not contraindicated for menstrual irregularities.

Option D: Endometriosis- D&C is not a primary treatment for endometriosis. The management of endometriosis typically involves hormonal therapy, pain management, or surgical interventions such as laparoscopy. However, D&C may be performed in certain cases for diagnostic purposes or to remove endometrial tissue in conjunction with other treatments.

questions.text: What is observed in cases of superfecundation?

choices.text: Fertilization of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at single intercourse
Fertilization of 2 ova released in the same cycle by sperms released at intercourse on 2 different occasion

questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Fertilization of 2 ova released in the same cycle by sperms released at intercourse on 2 different occasion

  • Fertilization of 2 ova released in the same cycle by sperms released at intercourse on two different occasions. This is the correct definition of superfecundation.
  • It occurs when a woman releases multiple eggs during a single menstrual cycle and each egg is fertilized by a different sperm from separate acts of intercourse occurring at different times.

Incorrect Options

Option A: Fertilization of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at a single intercourse. This scenario describes ordinary fraternal (dizygotic) twins, where two separate eggs are released and fertilized by two different sperm during a single act of intercourse. Superfecundation, however, involves the fertilization of ova released at different times within the same cycle.

Option C: Both of the above- This option is incorrect because option A describes fraternal twins, not superfecundation. Superfecundation specifically refers to the fertilization of multiple ova in the same cycle by sperms from different instances of intercourse.

Option D: None of the above- This option is also incorrect as option B accurately describes superfecundation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding peripartum cardiomyopathy?

choices.text: Development of cardiac failure within 5 months of delivery
Left ventricular end diastolic dimension more than 10 cm/m2 .

questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Left ventricular end diastolic dimension more than 10 cm/m2 .

  • Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction. This option is incorrect.
  • Peripartum cardiomyopathy primarily involves Left ventricular end diastolic dimension more than 2.7 cm/m2 .

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Development of cardiac failure within 5 months of delivery- This is true for peripartum cardiomyopathy. PPCM is defined as the development of heart failure symptoms and left ventricular dysfunction in the last month of pregnancy or within 5 months after delivery, excluding other known causes of heart failure.

Option C: Absence of identifiable cause- This is true for peripartum cardiomyopathy. The exact cause of PPCM is unknown, and there are no identifiable factors or conditions that can consistently predict its occurrence. It is considered idiopathic, meaning without a known cause.

Option D: Ejection fraction less than 45% - This is true for peripartum cardiomyopathy. Ejection fraction less than 45% is present.

questions.text: What is the most frequent manifestation of postpartum nerve injury among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Foot drop

  • Foot drop is the most common presentation of postpartum nerve injury.
  • Foot drop refers to the difficulty or inability to lift the front part of the foot properly, leading to a dragging or slapping gait.
  • It is most commonly caused by damage to the peroneal nerve, which innervates the muscles involved in foot dorsiflexion.
  • Postpartum nerve injury resulting in foot drop can occur due to various factors, including prolonged pressure on the nerves during labor or the use of forceps or vacuum extraction.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Facial palsy- Facial palsy, also known as Bell's palsy, is characterized by the weakness or paralysis of the muscles on one side of the face. It is most commonly caused by damage or inflammation of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). While facial palsy can occur in the postpartum period, it is not the most common presentation of postpartum nerve injury.

Option B: Wrist drop- Wrist drop refers to the inability to extend or lift the wrist properly. It is typically caused by injury or compression of the radial nerve, which runs along the back of the forearm. While nerve injuries can occur during childbirth, resulting in conditions like brachial plexus injury, wrist drop is not the most common presentation of postpartum nerve injury.

Option D: Claw hand- Claw hand refers to a deformity in which the hand appears with bent or curved fingers resembling a claw. It can result from different causes, including nerve injuries such as ulnar nerve compression or injury. However, claw hand is not typically associated with postpartum nerve injury as the most common presentation.

questions.text: What is altered in the thyroid profile throughout pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option - Total T3

  • Total T3 and Total T4 levels increase during pregnancy.
  • This is due to the elevated levels of estrogen, which increase the production of thyroid-binding globulin (TBG).
  • The increased TBG binds more thyroid hormones, resulting in higher total (but not free) thyroid hormone levels.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and D:

  • Free T3 and Free T4 levels typically remain within the normal range.
  • TSH levels may decrease slightly in the first trimester but generally stay within the normal range.

questions.text: A woman at 26 weeks of gestation gets an ultrasound done for fetal well-being and is diagnosed with hydrops fetalis. Which of the following fetal infections could have led to this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C

  • Hydrops fetalis is a condition characterized by abnormal fluid accumulation in fetal tissues and body cavities, resulting in significant swelling. It can be caused by various factors, including fetal infections. In this case, the infection most commonly associated with hydrops fetalis is Parvovirus B19 (Ans. C). Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to severe anemia in the fetus, causing congestive heart failure and subsequent hydrops fetalis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Epstein-Barr virus (Ans. A): Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is primarily associated with infectious mononucleosis and is not a common cause of hydrops fetalis.

Option B: Human papillomavirus (HPV) (Ans. B): HPV is a sexually transmitted infection that can cause genital warts and increase the risk of cervical cancer but is not typically associated with hydrops fetalis.

Option D: Influenza virus (Ans. D): Influenza virus infection during pregnancy can cause maternal complications and increase the risk of preterm labor, but it is not a common cause of hydrops fetalis.

questions.text: Cut off point for 50 gram glucose challenge test at 1 hour mg%?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • The 50-gram glucose challenge test is performed during pregnancy to screen for gestational diabetes. The test involves measuring the blood glucose level 1 hour after the ingestion of a 50-gram glucose solution. The cut-off point for a positive result is a blood glucose level equal to or greater than 140 mg% (Ans. B). If the result is positive, further testing with a glucose tolerance test (GTT) is usually recommended for confirmation.

Incorrect options:

Option A: 100: A blood glucose level of 100 mg% is not the cut-off point for the 50-gram glucose challenge test.

Option C: 180: A blood glucose level of 180 mg% is not the cut-off point for the 50-gram glucose challenge test.

Option D: 200: A blood glucose level of 200 mg% is not the cut-off point for the 50-gram glucose challenge test.

questions.text: A 30 year old primigravida female delivers a full term baby. However she choses to formula feed her newborn. After how much duration can she start using combined oral contraceptives for avoiding a pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • After delivery, it is generally recommended to wait for a certain duration before starting combined oral contraceptives (COCs) to avoid the risk of thromboembolic events. In the case of a woman who chooses to formula feed her newborn, she can start using COCs for contraception after 6 weeks postpartum (Ans. B). This waiting period allows the body to recover from childbirth and reduces the risk of complications associated with COC use.

Incorrect options: 

Option A: 2 weeks: Starting COCs just 2 weeks after delivery may increase the risk of thromboembolic events, and therefore, it is not the recommended duration to initiate COC use.

Option C: 12 weeks: Waiting for 12 weeks postpartum is not necessary for a woman who is formula feeding her newborn. Six weeks is a sufficient waiting period in such cases.

Option D: Immediately after delivery: COCs should not be initiated immediately after delivery due to the increased risk of thromboembolic events. A waiting period is advisable before starting COCs.

questions.text: The calculation of the EDD (Expected Date of Delivery) is determined by?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • The expected date of delivery (EDD) is calculated based on Naegele's formula, which is a commonly used method. According to Naegele's formula, the EDD is calculated by adding 280 days (40 weeks) to the first day of the woman's last menstrual period (LMP) and adjusting for the length of the menstrual cycle (usually assumed to be 28 days). Naegele's formula takes into account the average length of pregnancy, which is approximately 40 weeks from the LMP.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Young's rule: Young's rule is a method used for calculating pediatric drug dosages based on the child's age and weight. It is not relevant to calculating the expected date of delivery.

Option C: Cardiff Formula: There is no established "Cardiff Formula" for calculating the expected date of delivery.

Option D: Hadlock Formula: The Hadlock Formula is used for fetal biometric measurements and estimating gestational age during prenatal ultrasound examinations. It is not used for calculating the expected date of delivery.

questions.text: Which type of twinning is observed if a zygote undergoes division within 3 days of fertilization?
questions.solution:
Correct option C

  • When a zygote divides into two separate embryos 2-3 days after fertilization, it results in diamniotic, dichorionic twins. In this type of twinning, each embryo has its own amniotic sac (diamniotic) and placenta (dichorionic). The division occurs early enough for the embryos to develop their own individual structures.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Monochorionic, Monoamniotic: Monochorionic, monoamniotic twins result from the division of a zygote after the formation of the amniotic sac but before the development of the chorion. These twins share both the same amniotic sac and placenta.

Option B: Monochorionic, Diamniotic: Monochorionic, diamniotic twins occur when a zygote divides after the formation of both the amniotic sac and chorion. These twins share the same placenta but have separate amniotic sacs.

Option D: Dichorionic, Monoamniotic: Dichorionic, monoamniotic twins involve the splitting of a zygote after the formation of the chorion but before the development of the amniotic sac. These twins share the same placenta but have a single amniotic sac.

questions.text: In the case of failed medical management, which part of the fallopian tube is most likely to experience the earliest rupture of an ectopic sac?
questions.solution:
In the case of an ectopic pregnancy, the fallopian tube is the most common site of implantation. If medical management fails, the ectopic pregnancy may continue to grow, potentially leading to a rupture of the fallopian tube.

Option B. Isthmus: The isthmus is the narrowest part of the fallopian tube, located adjacent to the uterus. Typically, tubal ectopic pregnancies in the isthmus rupture within the first few weeks of gestation, with the ampulla being slightly more expandable . Other implantation sites, including the cornua and abdomen, allow for further gestational development due to increased space and ability to distend

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Interstitial: This option is incorrect

Option C. Ampulla: The ampulla is the most common site of ectopic pregnancies. Rupture of an ectopic pregnancy in the ampulla can cause significant abdominal pain and bleeding. It is a common site for tubal ectopic pregnancies.

Option D. Infundibulum: The infundibulum is the funnel-shaped distal end of the fallopian tube, close to the ovary. Ectopic pregnancies in this location are less common. Rupture in the infundibulum can also cause abdominal pain and internal bleeding.

questions.text: After 28 weeks of POG what is the  primary source of amniotic fluid secretion ?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • "Fetal urine.": During the later stages of pregnancy, particularly after 28 weeks of gestation, the primary source of amniotic fluid is fetal urine. The developing fetus continuously produces urine as a byproduct of its metabolic processes. The urine is then excreted into the amniotic sac, contributing to the volume of amniotic fluid.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Fetal skin: Fetal skin does contribute to the production of amniotic fluid, but it is not the major source. Fetal skin secretes a substance called vernix caseosa, which, along with other fetal skin cells and glandular secretions, contributes to the composition of amniotic fluid. However, the amount of fluid generated from fetal skin is relatively small compared to fetal urine.

Option C: Placental cell membrane: The placental cell membrane, also known as the amnion, plays a crucial role in enclosing the amniotic sac and protecting the fetus. While it does contribute to the overall volume of amniotic fluid, it is not the major source of fluid secretion. The amnion primarily acts as a barrier between the fetal and maternal circulation, rather than actively secreting fluid.

Option D: Plasma: Plasma refers to the fluid component of blood. While maternal blood does contribute to the composition of amniotic fluid through passive exchange across the placenta, it is not a significant source of fluid secretion compared to fetal urine.

questions.text: A G4P2 female presented with history of two abortions at 16 weeks and 20 weeks POG. Which of the following could be the most likely reason for these abortions?
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • Recurrent mid-trimester abortions (abortions occurring between 14 and 24 weeks of gestation) can be caused by various factors. One of the common causes is cervical incompetence, also known as cervical insufficiency. Cervical incompetence refers to the inability of the cervix to retain a pregnancy, leading to repeated second-trimester pregnancy losses.
  • In cervical incompetence, the cervix is structurally weak or lacks the normal ability to remain closed during pregnancy. As a result, the cervix may start to efface (thin out) and dilate prematurely, leading to the loss of the pregnancy. Cervical incompetence is often associated with painless cervical dilation and bulging of the amniotic sac through the cervix.
  • Other causes of mid-trimester abortions, such as chromosomal abnormalities, placenta previa, or thyroid abnormalities, can also contribute to pregnancy losses, but given the history provided, cervical incompetence is the most likely reason in this scenario.
  • Cervical incompetence, also known as an incompetent cervix or cervical insufficiency, is a condition where the cervix begins to dilate and efface prematurely during pregnancy, often leading to late miscarriages or preterm births.
  • In women with cervical incompetence, the cervix is unable to support the weight of the growing pregnancy, resulting in painless cervical dilation and pregnancy loss, typically occurring in the second trimester.
  • Cervical incompetence is a likely cause for recurrent mid-trimester miscarriages in this scenario.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Chromosomal abnormality: Chromosomal abnormalities can be a cause of pregnancy loss, but they are not specific to mid-trimester abortions.

Cervical incompetence, also known as an incompetent cervix or cervical insufficiency, is a condition where the cervix begins to dilate and efface prematurely during pregnancy, often leading to late miscarriages or preterm births. In women with cervical incompetence, the cervix is unable to support the weight of the growing pregnancy, resulting in painless cervical dilation and pregnancy loss, typically occurring in the second trimester. Cervical incompetence is a likely cause for recurrent mid-trimester miscarriages in this scenario.

Option C: Placenta previa: Placenta previa, a condition where the placenta partially or completely covers the cervix, is associated with third-trimester bleeding but not necessarily mid-trimester abortions.

Placenta previa, a condition where the placenta partially or completely covers the cervix, can lead to bleeding during the later stages of pregnancy. While placenta previa can cause complications, such as bleeding and preterm delivery, it is not the most probable cause for the described recurrent miscarriages.

Option D: Thyroid abnormality: Thyroid abnormalities can contribute to pregnancy complications, but they are not commonly associated with mid-trimester abortions.

Thyroid disorders, particularly uncontrolled hypothyroidism, can contribute to infertility and pregnancy complications. However, in the context of recurrent mid-trimester miscarriages, cervical incompetence is a more likely cause compared to thyroid abnormalities.

questions.text: A 32 year old pregnant woman presents with 36 weeks of gestation with complaints of pain abdomen and decreased fetal movements. On examination PR: 96/min, BP = 156/100 mm Hg, FHR = 128 bpm. On per-vagina examination there is altered blood seen and cervix is soft 1 cm dilated. What is the preferred management?
questions.solution:
Correct option: C. Immediate LSCS

  • The clinical presentation suggests that the patient may be experiencing placental abruption or another obstetric emergency, which requires immediate delivery to ensure the safety of both the mother and the fetus. Given her high blood pressure (which could indicate preeclampsia) and decreased fetal movements, immediate surgical intervention (LSCS - Lower Segment Cesarean Section) is the safest option.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Tocolytics

  • Explanation: Tocolytics are used to delay preterm labor, which is not appropriate here since the patient is already at 36 weeks and shows signs of potential placental abruption or another obstetric emergency.

Option B. Induce labour

  • Explanation: Inducing labor could be risky due to the altered blood seen on examination, indicating potential placental abruption. Immediate LSCS is safer to manage the condition.

Option D. Wait and watch

  • Explanation: Given the high blood pressure, abdominal pain, and decreased fetal movements, waiting could endanger both the mother and the fetus. Immediate action is required to prevent further complications.

questions.text: A primigravida presents at 9 weeks of amenorrhea with a positive pregnancy test. She complains of nausea and vomiting which gets better by evening. The doctor advices her folic acid and dietary modifications to help with her vomiting. He explains that the cause of such presentation is a hormone. The source of this hormone is?
questions.solution:
Correct option: C

  • The symptoms described by the patient, including nausea and vomiting that improve by evening, are characteristic of morning sickness (nausea and vomiting of pregnancy). The hormone responsible for causing morning sickness is human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which is primarily produced by the syncytiotrophoblast (a layer of the placenta).
  • During early pregnancy, hCG levels rise rapidly, peaking around 9-12 weeks of gestation. The exact mechanism by which hCG causes nausea and vomiting is not fully understood, but it is believed to involve interactions with the gastrointestinal system and hormonal pathways.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Yolk sac: The yolk sac plays a role in early embryonic development and nutrient transfer but is not the source of the hormone responsible for causing nausea and vomiting in pregnancy.

Option B: Fetal liver: The fetal liver is involved in various metabolic functions but is not the source of the hormone responsible for morning sickness.

Option D: Umbilical cord: The umbilical cord connects the fetus to the placenta and facilitates nutrient and oxygen transfer but is not the source of the hormone causing nausea and vomiting in pregnancy.

questions.text: Size of uterus (in inch):
questions.solution:
Correct option B

  • The correct option represents the size of the uterus as 3x2x1 inches. The other options provide different measurements that do not match the given size.

Incorrect options:

Option A: This option provides a different measurement than the given size of the uterus.

Option C: This option provides a different measurement than the given size of the uterus.

Option D: This option provides a different measurement than the given size of the uterus.

questions.text: Pearl index is used to calculate which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct option A

  • The Pearl index is a measure used to calculate the number of accidental pregnancies per 100 woman-years of exposure to a contraceptive method. It helps assess the effectiveness of different contraceptive methods in preventing unintended pregnancies. The other options are unrelated to the Pearl index.

Incorrect options:

Option B: The Pearl index is not used to calculate population statistics.

Option C: The Pearl index is not used to calculate the overall fertility rate.

Option D: The Pearl index is not used to calculate the number of abortions.

questions.text: What is the accurate description regarding the physiological alterations in the respiratory system during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is C: FRC (Functional Residual Capacity) decreases.

During pregnancy, there are several changes in the respiratory system to accommodate the needs of both the mother and the developing fetus. One of these changes is a decrease in the FRC, which refers to the volume of air remaining in the lungs at the end of normal expiration.

The decrease in FRC occurs due to a combination of factors. The enlarging uterus pushes against the diaphragm, reducing the available space for lung expansion. Additionally, hormonal changes during pregnancy, particularly the increased levels of progesterone, affect respiratory drive and can lead to a decrease in FRC.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Minute volume decreases by 50%: This statement is incorrect. During pregnancy, the minute volume, which represents the amount of air breathed in one minute, actually increases. The increase in minute volume is primarily due to an increase in tidal volume (the amount of air inhaled and exhaled during normal breathing) rather than an increase in respiratory rate.

Option B: Residual volume increases: This statement is also incorrect. Residual volume refers to the volume of air that remains in the lungs after a maximal exhalation. In pregnancy, residual volume does not typically increase. Instead, it may decrease slightly due to the upward displacement of the diaphragm by the growing uterus.

Option D: Total lung capacity increases: This statement is incorrect as well. Total lung capacity represents the maximum volume of air the lungs can hold. While certain lung volumes and capacities change during pregnancy, such as FRC, total lung capacity generally remains unchanged or may have only a slight increase.

questions.text: What would be the subsequent course of action for a multigravida woman at 33 weeks gestation who complains of epigastric pain, headache, visual symptoms, and has 3+ proteinuria?
questions.solution:
Correct  Option is D:

The next step of management is administration of intravenous MgSO4 (magnesium sulfate).

It acts as an anticonvulsant and helps prevent seizures in women with pre-eclampsia or those at risk of developing eclampsia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Immediate C-section - While delivery is the definitive treatment for pre-eclampsia, in this case, the immediate priority is to stabilize the patient's condition with MgSO4 administration before considering delivery.

Option B: Dexamethasone for fetal lung maturity - Fetal lung maturity is not the primary concern in this situation. The focus is on managing the maternal condition to prevent complications.

Option C: Induction - vaginal delivery - Inducing labor may be considered once the maternal condition is stable, but in the presence of severe pre-eclampsia, MgSO4 administration takes precedence to prevent seizures and manage the condition.

questions.text: Anti-D vaccine is not given in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is C: Intrauterine transfusion at 28 weeks: The Anti-D vaccine is not given in this situation to avoid the destruction of the Rh-positive blood cells being transfused. Intrauterine transfusion involves the direct transfusion of Rh-positive blood into the fetus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Amniocentesis at 16 weeks: The Anti-D vaccine can be administered to Rh-negative mothers after amniocentesis to prevent sensitization. This procedure does not involve the direct transfusion of Rh-positive blood.

Option B: Manual removal of placenta: The Anti-D vaccine can be administered to Rh-negative mothers after manual removal of the placenta to prevent sensitization. This procedure does not involve the direct transfusion of Rh-positive blood.

Option D: MTP at 63 days: If the fetus has Rh-positive blood, the Anti-D vaccine should be given to the Rh-negative mother after the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) to prevent sensitization. The administration of the Anti-D vaccine is not contraindicated in this scenario.

questions.text: What is one of the measures taken to manage atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)?   	Uterine massage is first step in the management 	Ergometrine is administered in all patients 	Manual removal of placenta is done 	B-Lynch suture is put if medical management fails
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B

  • 1 & 4 are correct: This option is correct. Uterine massage is indeed the first step in the management of atonic PPH as it helps stimulate uterine contractions. If medical management fails to control the bleeding, the B-Lynch suture can be performed. The B-Lynch suture is a surgical technique where a non-absorbable suture is placed around the uterus to compress it and control bleeding.

Incorrect option:

Option A. 1 & 2 are correct: This option is incorrect. Although uterine massage is an important initial step in the management of atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), the administration of ergometrine (also known as ergonovine) is not recommended in all patients with atonic PPH. Ergometrine is a uterotonic medication that helps in contracting the uterus, but it has side effects and contraindications, such as hypertension, which can limit its use.

Option C. 2 & 4 are correct: This option is incorrect. While the administration of ergometrine can be considered in the management of atonic PPH, it is not universally administered in all patients. The decision to use ergometrine depends on various factors, including the patient's medical history, blood pressure, and potential contraindications. Option 4 is correct because the B-Lynch suture can be considered if medical management fails.

Option D. 2 & 3 are correct: This option is incorrect. Although the administration of ergometrine can be considered in the management of atonic PPH, manual removal of the placenta is not a specific management step for atonic PPH. Manual removal of the placenta may be necessary

questions.text:
Assertion: In pregnancy, the definition of anemia is based on a higher cutoff of hemoglobin (Hb) compared to non-pregnant scenarios

Reason: Physiological hemodilution is seen in pregnancy

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, but the reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false
The assertion is false but reason is true

questions.solution:
Correct Ans: A.

  • Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion: This option is correct. In pregnancy, the definition of anemia is based on a higher cutoff of hemoglobin (Hb) compared to non-pregnant scenarios. Physiological hemodilution is a normal occurrence during pregnancy, where the blood volume expands more than the increase in red blood cell mass, leading to a relative dilution of the red blood cells. As a result, the Hb concentration may decrease slightly in pregnancy without indicating pathology. To account for this, higher cutoff values for Hb are used to define anemia during pregnancy compared to non-pregnant individuals.

Incorrect option:

Option B. Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion: This option is incorrect.
